title: President Trump Vows to Prioritize American Interests in World Trade Week Proclamation
content: President Trump's proclamation for World Trade Week focuses on prioritizing American workers and industries in trade policies.
resumen: Como parte de la observancia anual de la Semana Mundial del Comercio, el presidente Donald Trump enfatizó recientemente el enfoque de su administración en la recalibración de las políticas comerciales para priorizar los intereses estadounidenses. En una proclamación, Trump destacó medidas destinadas a fomentar relaciones comerciales equilibradas y recíprocas y expresó su apoyo a los trabajadores estadounidenses que, según él, han sido marginados previamente debido a la globalización. "Durante demasiado tiempo, las élites globalistas vendieron al trabajador estadounidense y permitieron que otros países tomaran injustamente nuestras fábricas, nuestros empleos y nuestros sueños. Esos días terminaron", declaró el Presidente en una proclamación emitida por la Casa Blanca. El Presidente subrayó su dedicación a la creación de un entorno más propicio para la creación de empleo nacional y el fortalecimiento industrial. Señaló que su administración ha sido proactiva en revertir la tendencia de la deslocalización, mediante la promulgación de aranceles y otras medidas comerciales. "Mi Administración está entregando ese futuro", dijo Trump, refiriéndose a una visión que articuló mientras hacía campaña para el cargo. "Desde que asumí el cargo, he tomado medidas para proporcionar una vida mejor para todos los estadounidenses y especialmente para los millones de estadounidenses que quedaron en el camino a medida que los empleos se enviaban al extranjero", según la Casa Blanca. La proclamación de la Casa Blanca también detalló los movimientos de política comercial destinados a frenar la importación de fentanilo y a promover la competitividad estadounidense en el extranjero. Elogió la introducción de nuevos acuerdos comerciales, como el acuerdo comercial entre Estados Unidos y el Reino Unido, que buscan crear oportunidades para las empresas estadounidenses a nivel internacional. El Presidente se comprometió a combatir las prácticas comerciales desleales que afectan a una amplia franja de la población estadounidense, desde "agricultores y pescadores hasta empresarios y todos los demás", según la Casa Blanca. Trump expresó una firme determinación de perpetuar una estrategia de "Estados Unidos primero" en todas las negociaciones comerciales y el desarrollo de políticas. "Como Presidente, siempre pondré los intereses de Estados Unidos primero", afirmó. "Juntos, construiremos una nueva Edad de Oro para Estados Unidos con un fuerte crecimiento económico y políticas comerciales de Estados Unidos primero que protejan a nuestros trabajadores, fortalezcan nuestras industrias y desbloqueen el Sueño Americano para todos los ciudadanos". El domingo pasado hasta ayer fueron designados como la Semana Mundial del Comercio, invitando a la celebración de las contribuciones del comercio estadounidense bajo la directiva de Trump, según lo detallado por la Casa Blanca.

title: Trump’s Pincer Strategy: Squeezing EU on Trade and Defense
content: The European Union (EU) faces significant pressure from the United States under President Donald Trump’s administration, driven by two distinct but ...
resumen:
The European Union (EU) faces pressure from the United States under President Donald Trump’s administration, driven by aggressive tariff threats and demands for increased NATO defense spending. These policies reflect Trump’s “America First” approach.

Trump announced a plan to impose a 50% tariff on EU imports starting June 1, 2025, citing stalled trade negotiations and a US trade deficit. He introduced a 20% tariff on EU goods in April 2025, paused for 90 days. The new 50% tariff threat surpasses the earlier 39% rate. Trump has threatened a 25% tariff on imported smartphones, including iPhones, by the end of June 2025.

The EU is preparing for potential retaliation. The European Commission, led by President Ursula von der Leyen, has vowed to respond “firmly and immediately” to any unjustified tariffs, with countermeasures worth approximately $28 billion already planned.

Economic analyses provide varied estimates of the tariffs’ impact. The Kiel Institute predicts a 20% drop in EU exports to the US and a 6% price increase for US consumers. Bruegel suggests a manageable GDP reduction of 0.11% for the EU. The German automobile industry faces particular risk, with potential export declines of nearly 20%. The Tax Foundation estimates a $1,200 tax increase per US household in 2025.

Trump has intensified pressure on NATO allies, particularly the 23 EU member states, to increase defense spending to 5% of GDP, a significant leap from the 2% target set in 2014. This demand reflects Trump’s view that Europe relies too heavily on US security guarantees.

In 2024, NATO’s European allies and Canada spent $485 billion on defense, equivalent to 2.02% of their combined GDP, with 22 of 32 allies meeting the 2% target. Poland led with 4.12%, followed by Estonia at 3.43%, while the US spent 3.38%. Projections for 2025 estimate EU NATO members’ spending at 2.04%.

European leaders have called Trump’s 5% target unrealistic. Germany’s Chancellor Olaf Scholz and others emphasize strengthening defense capabilities without committing to specific percentages. Some allies propose redefining defense spending to include nontraditional items like cybersecurity, aiming for a combined target of 3.5% military and 1.5% defense-related spending by 2032. Sweden plans to reach 2.4% in 2025 and 2.6% by 2028.

If implemented, Trump’s tariffs could trigger a trade war, reducing EU exports and increasing prices for US consumers. The German auto industry faces significant risks, with potential export declines of 20%. Retaliatory tariffs from the EU could further disrupt US exports. The CEPR estimates a modest EU GDP reduction of less than 1% over four years.

Trump’s NATO demands could push the EU toward greater defense self-reliance. A more militarized Europe could alter global security dynamics, particularly in countering Russia. The proposed redefinition of defense spending offers a compromise, but failure to meet Trump’s expectations could lead to US threats to scale back NATO commitments.

The dual pressures signal a shift toward a transactional US-EU relationship, where cooperation depends on EU concessions on trade and defense. This could weaken the alliance if European resentment grows. The outcome hinges on diplomatic efforts, with EU leaders like von der Leyen and Tusk emphasizing cooperation over conflict.

Saeed Minhas is the author.

title: Trade war tremors: A Q and A with a Kansas economist about tariffs, manufacturing and the workforce
content: The act passed in June 1930, under President Herbert Hoover, and it increased U.S. tariffs on agricultural imports and thousands of imported goods. Many economists credit it with deepening the Great ...
resumen:
Bekah Selby-Leach, director of the Wichita State University Center for Economic Development and Business Research, considers the trade war and the future of U.S. manufacturing.

A tariff is a tax on businesses bringing goods and services into the country, levied against domestic businesses to encourage them to produce locally.

The goal of putting tariffs in place could address trade imbalances. About one-third of goods and services are being produced out of the China region, putting them at a huge advantage in terms of their control of global markets, and the United States wants to reclaim some of that control.

Selby-Leach and economists nationwide are seeing slow-downs indicative of an approaching recession.

The short-term China trade deal led some analysts to reconsider but that news was quickly followed by a U.S. credit rating downgrade from Moody’s. That news caused mortgage rates to jump up near 7%. Yet inflation also increased at a lower-than-expected rate, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported.

If Trump trade deals don’t go right, it could very well lead to a deepening recession.

Current tariff policies in the United States are reminiscent of a similar situation from the past. The Smoot-Hawley Act, passed in June 1930, under President Herbert Hoover, increased U.S. tariffs on agricultural imports and thousands of imported goods. Many economists credit it with deepening the Great Depression because of retaliatory tariffs and causing decreased U.S. exports.

Tariffs almost always lead to inflation in prices.

Almost all goods the United States consumes have some portion of their supply chain that will be affected by tariffs.

Global economic power has shifted toward China for some time, and pulling some of that back would add more democracy to the global markets, with less centralization in one country.

Consumers will “most certainly” see rising costs of items typically purchased from abroad, even if companies move manufacturing to the United States.

Bringing manufacturing back to the U.S. isn’t as simple as it may appear to be.

Most of the richest countries in the world do not have a lot of production.

High-tech manufacturing can be considered its own new industry.

China has been working on advanced manufacturing for at least a decade. Advanced manufacturing refers to the use of robotics, artificial intelligence, automation and other high-tech advances. They have some production centers that have 500,000 workers. That’s the entire city of Wichita.

Low unemployment rates already create challenging workforce issues. There aren’t people who know how to do those things in the United States because we haven’t done them for so long. So you’d have to go through a huge human training program to develop those skills. That will take at least a couple of years.

There isn’t an available labor pool to reskill and place into newly created manufacturing jobs.

Places like Wichita, with its highly skilled workforce in the aerospace industry and other advanced manufacturers, would have an advantage.

Uncertainty has a very known effect and people tend to consume less and save more. They tend to invest less and hold onto their money in what they consider to be more stable places, such as a savings account, or even cash and assets like that.

The way we measure economic activity is through spending.

title: How American Retailers Are Navigating Trump’s Volatile Trade Policy
content: Observer spoke with dozens of retail CEOs and founders, consumer experts and supply chain strategists about how they are navigating tariffs.
resumen:
In 2025, tariffs have emerged as a new "force majeure" for American retailers due to erratic tariff policies tied to Trump’s second-term agenda. Businesses are facing a high-stakes guessing game in navigating pricing, planning, and logistics, with trade alliances dissolving overnight and tariff schedules changing rapidly. Preserving optionality is now a survival skill.

Companies are reengineering operations and supply chains to withstand what many call a “Trump majeure.” Bill London, an international attorney at Kimura London & White, notes that businesses are revisiting contracts to insert renegotiation clauses and price adjustment mechanisms triggered by tariff shifts.

Charlie Youakim, CEO and co-founder of Sezzle, observes that pure e-commerce retailers, especially those reliant on Chinese manufacturing, are scrambling, reworking logistics, and repricing inventory. While there's no panic, there is urgency.

Ross Widmoyer, CEO of Faribault Mill, has embraced a hyper-local model, sourcing inputs domestically, which has provided insulation and agility. Faribault Mill employs around 100 people and brings in nearly $20 million in annual revenue.

Steve Skillings, founder of BusyBox, faces shutting down due to skyrocketing component costs from tariffs.

Jason Wingate, co-founder of Zlumber, emphasizes the need for structural flexibility, including diversified suppliers, agile freight partners, and manufacturing options.

Many companies have relied on China for manufacturing, but this reliance is becoming precarious. Lee Mayer, CEO of Havenly Brands, is skeptical of rapid re-shoring due to price hikes. David’s Bridal has restructured its global supply chain, shifting production away from China. Mattel has reduced its manufacturing reliance on China. Ben Koren, CEO of Frameology, re-shored production years ago.

Companies are responding in different ways: shifting production, building structural flexibility, leaning into innovation, or engaging in policy advocacy. Emily Hosie, founder of REBEL, is lobbying for tariff exemptions on baby products. Keegan Nesvacil, CEO of Woodland Tools, describes a “design-for-resilience” model.

Many large brands have opted to stock up on inventory.

Resilience now depends on agility, optionality, and the recognition that there’s no cookie-cutter playbook.

title: Hang Seng Dips, Nikkei Gains as Trade Signals Drive Divergent Moves
content: Asian stock markets mixed as Trump’s tariff threats rattle Wall Street; Hang Seng dips, Nikkei gains on U.S.-Japan trade hopes.
resumen:
China’s state media warned of a prolonged US-China trade standoff, undermining hopes of a lasting deal.
The Hang Seng Index dipped 0.40% as trade jitters pressured property and tech stocks in early Monday trading.
The ASX 200 slipped 0.09% with Aussie bank stocks under pressure from higher US Treasury yields and weak sentiment.
US markets slumped as investors reacted to President Trump’s latest tariff threat.
The Nasdaq Composite Index slid 1%, while the Dow and S&P 500 dropped 0.61% and 0.67%, respectively.
On Friday, Trump threatened the EU with a 50% tariff, effective June 1.
The negative sentiment spilled into the Asian session on Monday, May 26.
CN Wire reported: “China must maintain a clear-eyed understanding of the challenges ahead, noting the U.S. may adopt delaying tactics to mitigate its economic losses. Given the enduring and complex nature of the confrontation, China must not only prepare thoroughly for negotiations but also brace for a prolonged struggle.”
Though the US and China recently agreed to a 90-day tariff pause, a lack of progress may spook investors as the deadline approaches.
Brian Tycangco, editor at Stansberry Research, commented: “As I’ve said previously, we just had a pause- not a deal. China isn’t under any illusion that this is an easy road to travel. Get ready for more volatility.”
The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.40% in early trade.
The Hang Seng Mainland Properties Index fell 0.10%, while the Hang Seng Tech Index rose 0.32%.
BYD Corp. (01211) and Li Auto (02015) rallied 1.97% and 1.07%, respectively.
The CSI 300 declined 0.17%, while the Shanghai Composite edged 0.05% lower.
Japan’s Nikkei 225 gained 0.88% on Monday morning as investors reacted to US-EU trade headlines.
On May 25, President Trump postponed the 50% tariff on EU goods from June 1 to July 9.
The US and Japan could resume trade talks as Japan’s top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa prepares to visit Washington.
The USD/JPY pair by 0.05% to 142.619.
Tokyo Electron (8035) and Softbank Group (9984) advancing 1.96% and 1.49%, respectively.
Australia’s ASX 200 slipped 0.09% in the morning session as elevated US Treasury yields weighed on demand for high-yielding Aussie bank stocks.
Commonwealth Bank of Australia fell 0.43%, while ANZ slid 1.08%.
Northern Star Resources rallied 0.81%, following gold’s 1.89% surge on May 23.
Volatility remains elevated amid fiscal uncertainty and tariff concerns.
US-China negotiations will remain central to near-term sentiment.
Investors should monitor stimulus cues from Beijing and global central banks.

title: The latest on Trump’s tariffs, his sweeping policy bill and Putin criticism
content: House Republicans are pushing to slash nearly $1 trillion from Medicaid and food stamps as part of the “big, beautiful bill” aimed at enacting President Donald Trump’s agenda. The legislation is ...
resumen:
• Tariffs: President Donald Trump said today he agreed to delay imposing a 50% tariff on European Union imports until July 9 after a “very nice call” with the president of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen. Trump said “talks will begin rapidly,” and von der Leyen said that “Europe is ready to advance talks swiftly and decisively.” The news came after the president ratcheted up his trade war Friday, threatening 50% tariffs on goods from the EU as early as June 1.
• Trump criticizes Putin: Trump said today he doesn’t know “what the hell happened” to Russian President Vladimir Putin and that he is “not happy with what Putin is doing” after Moscow launched its largest aerial attack of its three-year war on Ukraine overnight.
• Trump’s megabill: The fate of the president’s “big, beautiful bill” now lies in the Senate, where some Republicans are signaling resistance over the national debt, Medicaid and other elements of the sweeping spending and tax cuts package. Democrats are decrying the potential loss of benefits for millions of low-income Americans. Trump acknowledged today that some “fairly significant” changes could be coming for the bill.

title: Why Trump lashed out at Europe over trade
content: President Trump’s surprise tariff threat against the European Union came in the midst of deepening frustration on his economic team over the 27-nation bloc’s approach to taxes, regulations and China.
resumen: President Trump threatened to impose 50% tariffs on European imports starting June 1. Trump signaled that he plans to follow through on his threat, saying he is “not looking for a deal" with the EU. Trump’s economic team has been frustrated by what it says is the slow pace of talks. Trump’s advisers have privately expressed irritation to European officials that EU member nations’ differing trade priorities have slowed down the talks. They have complained about what they see as Europe’s cautious approach to the negotiations and what they call the EU’s reluctance to make concrete offers that address U.S. concerns, such as fees on streaming services, value-added taxes, automotive regulations and fines imposed against U.S. companies in antitrust cases. The U.S. has so far not secured a commitment from EU leaders to place new tariffs on Chinese industries. As part of separate trade negotiations with the U.S., the U.K. agreed to move toward imposing tariffs on Chinese steel. That helped seal the U.S.-U.K. trade deal that Trump announced this month. The U.S.-EU tensions boiled over Friday morning. In February, Trump said the EU “was formed in order to screw the United States.". The EU trade chief, Maroš Šefčovič, spoke on a call with U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer and Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick hours after Trump’s Truth Social post. After Friday’s call, Šefčovič said the EU is fully engaged in trade talks with the U.S., but is ready to defend its interests. The U.K. reached a deal with the U.S. this month that kept in place Trump’s 10% across-the-board tariffs on U.K. goods. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent raised concerns about the pace of trade talks to EU officials during a meeting of finance ministers in Canada this past week. The EU previously approved tariffs for 21 billion euros of U.S. imports, equivalent to around $24 billion, but put those duties on hold after the Trump administration announced its 90-day pause on some U.S. tariffs. It also proposed targeting a second set of goods, worth up to 95 billion euros, if negotiations with the U.S. break down. In a Fox News interview Friday, Bessent said he hoped the threat of 50% tariffs would “light a fire under the EU.". The EU’s trade chief traveled to Washington in April armed with proposals to cut both sides’ industrial tariffs and for the EU to buy more American energy and soybeans, but left empty-handed.

title: Emmanuel Macron touts France as ‘reliable’ partner for south-east Asia
content: French president’s visit to Vietnam, Indonesia and Singapore will portray Paris as more respectful than US or China ...
resumen: French President Emmanuel Macron has begun a six-day visit to Vietnam, Indonesia and Singapore. He will tout France and Europe as trade and security partners for a region buffeted by tensions between China and the US. Macron arrived in Vietnam late on Sunday. The push for closer trade and security co-operation from Macron is intended to contrast with an increasingly militarily assertive China and the imposition of tariffs by US President Donald Trump on export-reliant countries in the region. An official in the Elysée palace said, “France, along with the European Union, represents a partner that is both reliable, committed to issues of sovereignty, and respectful of their independence.” Trump last month hit Vietnam, Indonesia and other south-east Asian countries with some of his highest “reciprocal” tariff rates after China. The region’s search for new trade opportunities could strengthen ties with the EU. The French official said Macron would emphasise that the EU still backs international trade rules, unlike the current US administration. “We do not want a jungle where the law of the strongest prevails,” the official said. Security concerns will also be high on the agenda, given China’s increasingly assertive naval presence in the South China Sea and tensions with Taiwan. Macron has in the past focused diplomatic efforts on countries including China — where he made a state visit in 2023 — India and Japan, as part of his strategy of positioning France as an Indo-Pacific power. France has several overseas territories in the Indo-Pacific, including la Reunion and Mayotte, which are home to about 1.7mn people. Its naval frigates conduct patrols in the South China Sea and the country has several military bases in the vast region. Vietnam and Singapore already have free trade agreements with the EU, while Indonesia has been in talks to establish one. Vietnam, in October upgraded relations with France to the status of “comprehensive strategic partnership” — the highest level of diplomatic ties offered by Hanoi. Vietnam is stepping up efforts to diversify trade from the US, which accounts for a third of its exports, and to sign free trade agreements with countries in Asia, Africa and Latin America. In Hanoi, Macron is expected to discuss co-operation on economy, defence, security, and energy, according to Vietnamese state media. An agreement on a power transmission line is among one of the deals expected to be signed. After Vietnam, Macron will head to resource-rich Indonesia, where President Prabowo Subianto is seeking foreign investments to spur a slowing economy. Indonesia has previously bought French defence equipment, including Rafale fighter jets and Scorpène submarines. “There may be other contracts announced during the trip,” said Céline Pajon, who heads Japan and Indo-Pacific research at the French Institute of International Relations think-tank. “France and Indonesia intend to raise the defence partnership into something long-term and structural.” The Indonesian government said in a statement this month that Macron’s visit reflected “the commitment of both countries to enhance co-operation in facing global challenges”. Macron plans to discuss diversification of France’s access to materials critical for production of smartphones and semiconductors while in Indonesia. During his final stop of the trip in Singapore, Macron will give a speech at the Shangri-La Dialogue, Asia’s largest defence forum. “It is the first time a European leader has been invited to give this speech, and it is in recognition of how Macron has developed a real Indo-Pacific strategy. He also encouraged the EU to adopt one as well,” Pajon said.

title: US-EU trade tensions 'to heighten economic uncertainty' as EU trade commissioner urges 'respect not threats' from US
content: Concerns over a US-EU trade war have been rising over the weekend as the US threatened to impose a 50 percent tariff on the EU and the bloc refused to back down, shaking global markets. The US-EU ...
resumen: US-EU trade tensions are rising as the US threatened to impose a 50 percent tariff on the EU, and the bloc refused to back down, shaking global markets. The US-EU trade tensions will add more economic uncertainty to the world, according to a Chinese expert. The EU trade commissioner, MaroÅ¡ Å efÄoviÄ, said any potential trade deal between Brussels and Washington must be based on "respect not threats." The US president claimed that "the EU, which was formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the US on TRADE, has been very difficult to deal with," and recommended a straight 50 percent Tariff on the EU, starting on June 1, 2025. The US president later escalated his message to the EU - "I'm not looking for a deal," he said. The tariff threat came amid stalled negotiations, with Washington demanding unilateral concessions from Brussels to open up to US business, while the EU has been seeking an agreement that offers mutual gain. The US president's latest remarks follow his April 2 "Liberation Day" announcement of a 39 percent tariff on European goods. US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Friday he hopes a new tariff threat from the president would speed along talks with the EU regarding a new trade deal. In a Friday interview with Fox News, Bessent accused the EU of not engaging in "good faith" trade negotiations with the White House. Zhou Mi, a senior research fellow at the Chinese Academy of International Trade and Economic Cooperation, said the US seems eager to ramp up pressure on the EU, possibly due to growing concerns about its domestic economy. The S&P 500 lost 0.7 percent Friday and had its worst week in the last seven. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.6 percent, and the Nasdaq composite sank 1 percent. The benchmark STOXX 600 index was down 0.93 percent. Germany's DAX fell by 1.54 percent and France's CAC index slid 1.65 percent. The US was the largest partner for EU exports of goods in 2024, making up 20.6 percent of exports, according to Eurostat. Petroleum oils, medicinal and pharmaceutical products were the EU's most exported group to the US last year. Zhou said that the current unpredictability - driven by tit-for-tat rhetoric - is putting stress on businesses on both sides, including American companies. The French trade minister, Laurent Saint-Martin, said the US' new threats did nothing to help negotiations. Irish Taoiseach MicheÃ¡l Martin described the US proposal of imposing 50 percent tariffs on the EU as "extremely disappointing." Huo Jianguo, a vice chairman of the China Society for World Trade Organization Studies in Beijing, said the EU is one of the US' largest economic partners and remains a significant global power and the US' threat of a 50 percent tariff reflects its eagerness to reach a deal with the EU. A Harris Poll for Bloomberg News found that a majority of US adults, 56 percent, said their household finances would be better off if the US tariffs had not been implemented. The World Economic Situation and Prospects as of mid-2025 recently released by the UN mentioned that higher tariffs and trade policy uncertainty have weakened the global economic outlook for 2025.

title: Trump Agrees To Extend 50% Tariffs On Europe Until July 9: 'It Was My Privilege To Do So'
content: Trump agreed to extend tariff deadline to July 9, 2025 after receiving call from Ursula von der Leyen, amid ongoing trade tensions between US and EU.
resumen: Donald Trump announced on Sunday that he received a call from Ursula von der Leyen, the President of the European Commission, requesting an extension on the impending 50% tariff deadline. The original deadline was set for June 1, but Trump agreed to extend it to July 9, 2025. Trump stated on Truth Social that the Commission President assured him that negotiations would commence swiftly. Trump expressed his willingness to grant the extension, describing it as his “privilege to do so.” Von der Leyen said on X that she had a “good call” with Trump. She had requested time until July 9 to reach a “good deal.” Trump’s decision to extend the deadline follows his previous threat to impose a 50% tariff on all European Union imports.

title: Trump Delays E.U. Tariffs Until July 9
content: President Trump said he would give the European Union more time to negotiate a trade deal before 50 percent tariffs take effect.
resumen:
President Trump said on Sunday that he would delay imposing 50 percent tariffs on all imports from the European Union until July 9 to allow more time for trade negotiations.

Mr. Trump said that he had spoken to Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, about his recent threat to enact the tariffs on June 1 if a trade deal could not be reached in the next week.

Mr. Trump has expressed frustration over negotiations with the E.U., saying that the union has been slow to offer trade concessions during a 90-day window to reach a deal that satisfies the administration.

On Sunday, Mr. Trump appeared to relent, at least for now.

“The Commission President said that talks will begin rapidly,” Mr. Trump wrote, referring to Ms. von der Leyen.

Ms. von der Leyen, in a separate social media post on Sunday, said that she had a “good call” with Mr. Trump and had conveyed to him that the E.U. needed extra time to reach a trade deal. She said that talks would advance “swiftly and decisively.”

The extension is the latest turnabout by Mr. Trump.

While announcing his recommendation for 50 percent E.U. tariffs on Friday, the president had assailed Europe’s negotiating tactics and expressed no interest in reaching a deal.

Friday’s threat of 50 percent tariffs came after Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent met with European counterparts as part of the Group of 7 meetings in Canada.

Mr. Bessent had given no indication to his counterparts that new tariffs were coming, but he defended them on Friday.

The Treasury Secretary said that Europe has a “collective action” problem and that individual countries in the E.U. did not know how Brussels was negotiating.

Mr. Trump’s tariff threat against the E.U. came weeks after he agreed to partially pause the 145 percent tariffs he had imposed on Chinese imports.

European officials held a call with their American counterparts for trade talks on Friday, and had earlier submitted a term sheet detailing their offers to secure a deal.

European leaders have offered to reduce tariffs on industrial goods to zero if the United States does the same, and to increase purchases of U.S. energy, among other commitments.

In a post on Truth Social Friday morning, Mr. Trump wrote that discussions with the European Union were “going nowhere” and that he was recommending a 50 percent tariff on European imports as of June 1.

Mr. Trump also threatened a 25 percent tariff on imports of smartphones made by Apple and other companies on Friday, saying they should be made in the United States.

Economists at Oxford Economics said that if implemented, the E.U. tariffs and the phone tariffs, combined, would reduce economic growth by 0.2 percentage points, raise inflation by 0.2 percentage points, and increase the unemployment rate by a tenth of a percentage point.

The economists, Ryan Sweet and Bernard Yaros, wrote that the proposed tariffs on the E.U. highlight a key forecast risk, whereby tariffs remain an ongoing tool to be wielded by the Trump administration whenever negotiations hit a snag.

title: Japanese Yen and Aussie Dollar Forecasts: Trade and Central Bank Pivots in Focus
content: AUD/USD climbs on tariff fears, but recession risks linger. RBA and Fed cues, US-China trade headlines, and Beijing policy in sharp focus.
resumen:
Trade tensions spike as Trump threatens 50% EU tariffs, sending USD/JPY down 1.01% on risk-off sentiment.
USD/JPY dropped below 143 on risk-off sentiment.
AUD/USD faces downside risk as US-China trade tensions may weigh on Aussie exports and RBA policy outlook.
Japan’s economy will be in focus on Monday, May 26, influencing the Bank of Japan rate path and USD/JPY trends.
According to preliminary data, the Leading Economic Index dropped from 108.2 in February to 107.7 in March.
A downward revision may temper bets on a Q3 2025 BoJ rate hike, potentially lifting USD/JPY.
A higher print could revive speculation of a Q3 hike, especially after April’s hotter-than-expected core inflation.
A more hawkish BoJ stance may drag the USD/JPY lower.
Economists had already pared back Q3 rate hike bets ahead of Friday’s inflation figures due to escalating tariff concerns.
A Reuters poll (May 7–13) showed: 67% of economists (39 of 58) anticipate no policy change in Q3, up from 36% in April.
52% forecast a 25-basis-point rate hike in 2025.
USD/JPY dropped 1.01% on Friday after President Trump threatened a 50% tariff on EU imports, boosting demand for safe-haven assets like the Yen.
Later in the session, Fed speakers will influence US dollar demand and USD/JPY trends.
Support for a Q3 2025 Fed rate cut could weigh on the US dollar and send USD/JPY toward the 140.309 support level.
Calls to delay rate cuts to assess inflationary impacts from tariffs may drive the pair toward the May 20 high of 145.507.
Bearish USD/JPY Scenario: Rising trade tensions, strong Japanese economic data, or dovish Fed rhetoric could drag USD/JPY toward 140.309.
Bullish USD/JPY Scenario: Easing trade friction, weak Japanese economic indicators, or hawkish Fed cues may lift USD/JPY toward 145 and potentially the 50-day EMA.
On May 26, US-China trade headlines and policy updates from Beijing will influence AUD/USD price action.
On Sunday, May 25, CN Wire reported that Chinese state media emphasized the unresolved nature of the US-China trade conflict, warning that talks would be “protracted and arduous.”
The commentary cited US delay tactics and the risk of renewed escalation if US political and economic pressures ease.
The report concluded that China must prepare for prolonged negotiations and a sustained confrontation.
A prolonged trade war may impact Aussie trade terms, given China accounts for one-third of Australian exports.
With a trade-to-GDP ratio above 50%, weaker demand from China could pressure the RBA into adopting a more dovish stance.
RBA Governor Michele Bullock recently warned that a worsening trade war could push Australia into recession.
She noted: “Australia’s economy could easily be compromised if a trade war between the US and China escalates… The market path is reflecting a possibility of a really bad outcome, pointing to a lower RBA cash rate.”
Rising recession fears and a more dovish RBA rate path may weigh on AUD/USD.
Bearish Aussie dollar Scenario: Renewed US-China tensions, Beijing withholds fresh stimulus, or dovish RBA cues may send AUD/USD toward the 200-day EMA.
Bullish Aussie dollar Scenario: Easing US-China trade tensions, Beijing stimulus, or hawkish RBA signals could send the pair toward the May 14 high of $0.65008.
Later today, US monetary policy will also affect AUD/USD.
Hawkish Fed rhetoric may widen the US-Aussie interest rate differential, potentially pulling AUD/USD toward the 200-day EMA.
Dovish cues favoring a Q3 Fed rate cut would narrow the rate differential, sending the pair toward $0.65008.
Traders should also monitor US fiscal risks and global trade rhetoric.
On May 23, AUD/USD rose 1.29% to $0.64914 as markets digested Trump’s tariff threat on EU imports and growing concerns over US debt levels.
Key Market Drivers to Watch Today: USD/JPY: US-Japan trade talks, Japanese economic data, and BoJ signals.
USD/JPY and AUD/USD: Fed speeches, US economic data, and global trade headlines.
AUD/USD: US-China relations, RBA commentary, and Beijing’s policy stance.

title: ‘The best chance we’ve got’: Can Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent save the world from trade Armageddon?
content: As President Donald Trump conducted an impromptu news conference in Doha, Qatar, this month, surrounded by business leaders and top advisers, he made a point of singling out one person in particular.
resumen:
En una conferencia de prensa improvisada en Doha, Qatar, el presidente Donald Trump destacó a Scott Bessent, Secretario del Tesoro, quien había asegurado un acuerdo para pausar temporalmente la guerra comercial entre EE. UU. y China. Trump elogió a Bessent, afirmando que los mercados escuchan cuando él habla. Bessent, conocido por su discreción, respondió que tenían un plan y un mecanismo para evitar la escalada comercial.

Bessent es considerado el funcionario económico más importante del mundo, siendo el principal negociador de Trump con China, liderando conversaciones comerciales con otros países y participando en la elaboración de un paquete fiscal y de gasto. También es responsable de mantener el papel dominante de Estados Unidos en el sistema financiero global.

Bessent se ha convertido en una figura clave en la administración, ganándose la confianza de legisladores, funcionarios y ejecutivos. Ha tenido éxito en luchas internas para consolidar su rol y es visto por Wall Street como la mejor esperanza para moderar las políticas económicas de Trump.

Antes de unirse a la administración, Bessent estudió la biografía de William McKinley, un ídolo de Trump en materia de aranceles. Aunque subestimó el entusiasmo de Trump por los aranceles, escribió a inversores que era poco probable que se implementaran aranceles generalizados al mismo tiempo que se abordaba la crisis migratoria.

Bessent, ausente de la Casa Blanca y los medios de comunicación durante una reunión de ministros de finanzas del G7 en Canadá, fue objeto de comentarios sobre su importancia. Trump anunció la recomendación de aranceles del 50% a la Unión Europea y del 25% a los iPhones de Apple. Bessent, en Nueva York, fue entrevistado en Fox News y Bloomberg TV.

Antes de ser Secretario del Tesoro, Bessent participó en una operación financiera exitosa en 1992, trabajando para el fondo de cobertura de George Soros. Su experiencia incluye estudios en Yale y el trabajo con Jim Rogers, quien lo introdujo al mundo de las finanzas.

En 2017, Bessent buscó entender la administración Trump, conectando con Steve Bannon para comprender la visión económica de Trump. Bessent donó a republicanos y mantuvo relaciones positivas en Wall Street.

Bannon considera a Bessent un jugador clave en la gestión del mercado de bonos. Cuando las conversaciones lideradas por Bessent con China llevaron a una desescalada arancelaria, Bannon defendió a Bessent.

Bessent tiene una relación de larga data con la familia Trump y ha sido un defensor de causas LGBTQ. En una entrevista, Bessent relató un momento en el Despacho Oval con su familia, donde presenciaron el trabajo del gobierno.

Bessent predijo la victoria de Trump en 2023, basándose en el análisis de las acciones que suben con las malas noticias. Su decisión de ayudar a la campaña de Trump se basó en su preocupación por la deuda de EE. UU.

Bessent ha influido en las políticas de Trump, como la pausa en los aranceles. Su enfoque en el rendimiento del Tesoro a 10 años es notable.

En la Conferencia Global del Instituto Milken, Bessent explicó que los componentes principales de la agenda económica de Trump (comercio, recortes de impuestos y desregulación) son partes interconectadas de un motor diseñado para impulsar la inversión a largo plazo en la economía estadounidense.

Los asesores económicos de Trump enfatizan que su agenda incluye incentivos fiscales y regulatorios, junto con los aranceles, para impulsar la inversión y el crecimiento. Los aranceles están diseñados para encajar en un marco más amplio que se centra en los recortes de impuestos y la desregulación.

La agenda busca equilibrar los incentivos fiscales y la desregulación con los aranceles, para evitar una recesión. Si alguno de estos elementos falla, la política económica podría colapsar.

title: Trump: El de siempre (IV)
content: Al margen de la confusión sobre los por qué y para qué de los aranceles y sobre la metodología para su determinación, lo que hay que decir es que los aranceles se sitúan en el centro de una ...
resumen:
Los aranceles se sitúan en el centro de una política económica global destinada a reindustrializar Estados Unidos. Trump quiere transformar el sistema económico internacional presionando el dólar a la baja para acabar con las asimetrías que enfrenta el comercio estadounidense afectando negativamente a su industria manufacturera.

Trump ha decidido imponer tres tipos de aranceles:

a) Un arancel mundial (global) del 10 % destinado a ser permanente.
b) Aranceles "recíprocos" que son en realidad "correctivos" para reequilibrar la balanza comercial de los países con los que Estados Unidos tiene un déficit.
c) Aranceles dirigidos específicamente contra China como parte de la intención de revocar el estatus de China como país beneficiario del régimen de relaciones comerciales normales permanentes (PNTR) y tras el objetivo de "China Out".

Trump presiona a México y Canadá para que redefinan sus aranceles con China de acuerdo con el objetivo estadounidense de "China Out".

Se trata de imponer:

a) Un arancel mundial permanente para abrir paso a la producción manufacturera estadounidense, mejorar los salarios de sus decenas de miles de obreros mal pagados y dar ocupación a los que, se dice, viven de la mendicidad y las drogas.
b) Un arancel permanente para China para desacoplar su economía de la estadounidense y acabar con la presencia China en el mundo.
c) Aranceles "recíprocos" como medio de presión para alentar a los socios comerciales de EEUU a tomar decisiones políticas para reducir los déficits.

El arancel mundial del 10 % se aplicará sobre casi todas las importaciones. Eximir a México y Canadá del 10% se debe a que estos dos países están sujetos a otros aranceles específicos y a la decisión trumpiana de querer renegociar el Acuerdo Estados Unidos-México-Canadá (USMCA).

Los aranceles "correctivos", responden a la lógica: ¿Quieres un arancel más bajo? ¡Corrige tu desequilibrio! Pueden negociarse país por país. Son temporales.

Trump, ha recogido las sugerencias de sus asesores económicos, pero ha primado su impronta beligerante y confrontacional.

Corea del Sur, por boca de su primer ministro interino Han Duck-soo, ha dicho que su país está "dispuesto a hacer concesiones para complacer a Trump porque EEUU ha hecho mucho por su crecimiento y desarrollo". Y ha marcado distancia con China para contrarrestar los aranceles.

title: Trump threatens 50% tariffs on EU imports amid growing tensions over trade and China
content: White House frustration with Europe’s pace and position in trade talks leads to surprise tariff warning ahead of June 1 deadline.
resumen: Donald Trump threatened to impose 50% tariffs on European Union imports starting June 1. This move was in response to the EU's handling of trade talks, regulation, and its stance on China. The Wall Street Journal reported the news. Trump officials have been pressing European diplomats to address US concerns over digital taxes, auto regulations, and antitrust penalties, while also pushing the EU to impose tariffs on Chinese goods. The UK accepted this measure in its recent deal with the US. Trump posted his 50% tariff warning on Truth Social. Trump told reporters later in the Oval Office that he intends to proceed unless the EU meets US expectations swiftly. The Trump administration demands coordinated tariffs on Chinese industries, particularly in steel and tech. US negotiators want the EU to join a broader front to pressure Beijing over subsidies and market interference. EU officials remain wary of provoking a trade war with China. US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told Fox News that the threat of tariffs was intended to “light a fire under the EU.” EU trade chief Maroš Šefčovič warned that “mutual respect, not threats,” must guide negotiations. The EU is ready to engage but would defend its interests if talks collapse. The 27-member bloc is considering retaliatory options. The EU has also prepared a second list targeting up to €95 billion in US exports should talks fail. The June 1 deadline looms as a critical turning point.

title: Trade war reload: Trump threatens EU with massive tariff
content: Economic projections estimate a potential 1.5 per cent drop in US GDP if the tariff is implemented and Capital Economics projects that Ireland could see a 4 per cent hit to its output, with Germany, ...
resumen:
On May 23, US President Donald Trump announced plans to impose a 50 per cent tariff on all European Union (EU) imports starting June 1, unless the bloc makes major concessions in ongoing trade talks.

Trump stated that the EU has been difficult to deal with, citing trade barriers, VAT taxes, corporate penalties, non-monetary trade barriers, monetary manipulations, and lawsuits against American companies, leading to a trade deficit with the US of more than $250,000,000 a year.

The comments marked a dramatic shift after weeks of de-escalation and a temporary 90-day pause in reciprocal tariffs.

The markets responded with immediate volatility. US and European stocks plunged, with Germany’s DAX down 2.4 per cent, France’s CAC falling 2.2 per cent, and the STOXX600 sliding 1.7 per cent. The US dollar weakened sharply, while gold prices surged.

The White House’s plan to double down on tariffs was reportedly driven by frustration over slow EU negotiations. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the president is dissatisfied with the EU’s offers.

In 2024, the EU exported goods worth approximately €500 billion ($566 billion) to the US, led by Germany (€161 billion), Ireland (€72 billion), and Italy (€65 billion). The US ran a $236 billion goods trade deficit with the EU in 2024.

Trump had previously lowered his 145 per cent tariff on Chinese goods to 30 per cent and retained a 10 per cent baseline tariff on most global imports.

EU trade chief Maroš Šefčovič emphasized that Brussels remains committed to a deal but will defend its interests if provoked. French Trade Minister Laurent Saint-Martin criticised Trump’s comments as “unhelpful”, and Irish Prime Minister Micheál Martin warned the tariffs would “grievously damage one of the world’s most dynamic and significant trading relationships.”

The EU has already paused tariffs on €23 billion ($26.15 billion) worth of US goods and has prepared up to €95 billion ($1.08 trillion) in countermeasures if talks fail.

Julian Hinz, a researcher at the Kiel Institute for the World Economy, estimated that a 50 per cent tariff could reduce US GDP by 1.5 per cent, while Capital Economics projected Ireland could see a 4 per cent hit to its economy.

The Trump administration is pushing the EU to align more closely with US policy on China.

The EU has suspended tariffs on $26 billion worth of US goods and has prepared retaliatory measures on up to $108 billion in exports should negotiations break down.

The Kiel Institute for the World Economy estimates a potential 1.5 per cent drop in US GDP if the tariff is implemented. Capital Economics projects that Ireland could see a 4 per cent hit to its output, with Germany, Italy, France, and Spain also suffering notable slowdowns.

Moody’s recently downgraded the US credit outlook.

Walmart’s earnings in the second half of the year are not optimistic.

Consumer spending is two thirds to three quarters of GDP in the United States, so now you’re facing a recession that’s inflation based.

title: La tregua global de los aranceles llega a su ecuador sin apenas avances
content: Trump solo ha llegado a un acuerdo de mínimos con Reino Unido, un país cercano y con el que tiene superávit; No se conocen progresos en el diálogo con Japón, Corea del Sur y la UE ...
resumen:
La tregua global de los aranceles llega a su ecuador sin apenas avances.

Donald Trump solo ha llegado a un acuerdo de mínimos con Reino Unido, un país cercano y con el que tiene superávit.

No se conocen progresos en el diálogo con Japón, Corea del Sur y la UE.

Donald Trump amenaza a la UE con un arancel del 50% a partir de junio.

Bruselas pide "respeto, no amenazas".

La tregua de 90 días declarada por el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, para negociar nuevos pactos arancelarios alcanzó su ecuador con escasos avances más allá de un acuerdo de mínimos con Reino Unido y una necesaria tregua paralela con China, a lo que hay que sumar nuevas amenazas del neoyorquino contra la Unión Europea (UE).

Trump volvió a endurecer su envite diciendo que las conversaciones “no están yendo a ningún lado” y que por ello activará gravámenes del 50 % sobre todos los bienes de la UE a partir del 1 de junio.

El comisario europeo de Comercio, Maros Sefcovic, dijo que la UE está dispuesta a defender sus intereses.

El diplomático eslovaco instó a que las relaciones comerciales bilaterales “se guíen por el respeto mutuo y no por las amenazas”.

Lo acordado en la reunión de hace dos semanas en Suiza entre representantes estadounidenses y chinos es probablemente la mejor noticia.

Las dos principales economías del mundo lograron sentarse a la mesa y acordar una tregua paralela de 90 días que entró en vigor el 14 de mayo.

La tregua con Pekín implica, entre otras cosas, que China reducirá del 125 % al 10 % los aranceles sobre productos estadounidenses y que EE.UU. rebajará los suyos del 145 % al 30 %.

Establece además un mecanismo por el cual podrán celebrarse alternativamente nuevas reuniones en cualquiera de los dos países o incluso en un tercer Estado y también consultas de trabajo sobre cuestiones técnicas.

Washington solo ha sellado un acuerdo con Londres en estos primeros 45 días del periodo de suspensión de los “aranceles recíprocos”.

El acuerdo con Reino Unido es en realidad un marco muy esquemático sobre el que ambas partes teóricamente deben seguir trabajando.

El pacto implica la entrada de una partida razonable de automóviles británicos con un gravamen de solo el 10 %, elimina impuestos aduaneros a los escasos volúmenes de acero y aluminio que el Reino Unido envía a EEUU y cancela también los aranceles que Washington aplicaba a sus componentes de aviación.

Todo a cambio de un futuro acuerdo de compra de aviones de Boeing por parte de British Airways y una mayor entrada de productos bovinos estadounidenses al Reino Unido cuyo alcance no está del todo claro.

Washington ha alcanzado este acuerdo con un aliado cercano con el que mantiene un superávit comercial.

EEUU debe alcanzar en estos 90 días acuerdos con economías asiáticas de peso y un músculo exportador destacado, como Japón, Corea del Sur o Indonesia, países que, como China o la UE, tienen grandes superávits con la primera potencia mundial y que pueden verse seriamente perjudicados si Trump activa finalmente los aranceles que les adjudicó inicialmente (un 24 %, 25 % y 32 %, respectivamente).

title: Emerging From Conflict, India Faces Trade And Investment Headwinds
content: India is emerging after a brief conflict with Pakistan, with a ceasefire thankfully appearing to hold for now. This is welcome news for the business community and the public at large, many of whom too ...
resumen: India is emerging from a brief conflict with Pakistan, with a ceasefire holding. Indian policymakers are returning to address economic policy priorities, including accelerating economic growth (higher than the current 6% pace), concluding a free trade agreement with America, and attracting foreign investment inflows away from China, with Apple being a top priority. India is likely to face considerable headwinds on each of these fronts. The recent India-Pakistan conflict serves as a reminder that while India enjoys relatively high growth rates, investors have “several options” when looking at changes to global supply chains. The Modi government’s third term has largely been devoid of significant reforms compared to its first two terms. The Commerce Ministry hopes to complete negotiations with America on an FTA in July. The government has been encouraged by Apple CEO Tim Cook’s recent comments that India was well-positioned to become a major manufacturing hub for the company’s iPhones. India’s promiscuous moves to conclude FTAs with major trading partners in record time will likely boost short-term growth. India’s entrenched business elite is notoriously protectionist. The Modi government had to withdraw controversial legislation to reform farming and lower tariffs agreed on specific sectors. The Modi government’s “Make in India” manufacturing plan is contingent upon Apple significantly scaling production of iPhones in the country. CEO Tim Cook recently told analysts that a majority of iPhones sold in America will have India as their country of origin. This comment drew an immediate rebuke from President Trump, who told Cook that “we’re not interested in you building in India.” The U.S. President followed that threat by posting on social media that he would introduce a 25% tariff on any smartphone imported into America. India needs plenty of Apple-like production facilities to lift manufacturing share of GDP (currently at 16% compared with China’s hefty 26%) as well as to provide quality jobs for millions of young people entering the job market each year. India’s vast population and internal market can remain the growth driver if trade and foreign investment initiatives falter. The government will have to introduce significant reforms designed at making the economy more productive, competitive, and inclusive. The overwhelming message for Indian policymakers therefore should be to focus less on the noise (Trump tariffs) and more on the signal (faltering growth in the absence of reforms).

title: What is behind Donald Trump's 50% tariff on EU imports to the US?
content: What is behind the US president Donald Trump's 50% tariff on EU imports to the US? RTÉ's Washington correspondent Sean Whelan looks at the latest developments on both sides of the Atlantic as well as ...
resumen: Donald Trump announced a 50% tariff on EU imports to the US, which caused a reaction in financial markets. The policy shift came unexpectedly, with the tariff starting on June 1st. Trump stated that there would be no tariff if the EU built plants in the US. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the 50% suggestion was to speed up negotiations and force the EU to make a "high quality offer." Bessent also mentioned that the EU proposals have not been of the same quality as other trading partners. The US has accused the EU of not negotiating in good faith. The EU's approach is not to escalate tensions, engage in megaphone diplomacy, or try to remove emotion from the equation. The general EU tariff rate of 20% has been raised by Mr. Trump to 50%. Euro zone government bond yields fell sharply following Donald Trump's announcement. Trump said the EU has not treated the US properly and that they banded together to take advantage of the US. He also mentioned a $17 billion lawsuit from Apple. The US president also announced a 25% Tariff on Apple iphones, unless they are made in the USA. The EU needs to help the US find ground which they can easily take and then declare victory, before a real and deeply damaging trade war begins. The US is looking for fundamental change, and it is most unlikely - certainly not within the very tight negotiating deadlines the president has set. The two sides cannot even agree on the extent of the trade surplus the EU runs with the US. The EU side includes the trade in services, where the US has a big surplus that reduces the trade gap to about $150 billion in the EU’s favour. The Americans say the gap is more like $250 billion. The EU needs a more dynamic financial services sector. The EU has a whole book of detailed analysis and recommendations on the topic, one commissioned by the EU’s political leaders, the heads of state and government, called the Draghi report - after its author, former ECB President and former Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi.

title: Aranceles de Trump podrían obstaculizar solución a crisis en Haití
content: Problemas que ha creado el gobierno del presidente Trump con el mundo entero, especialmente con México y Canadá en materia de aranceles, pudieran ser serios obstáculos para que los países de la ...
resumen:
Los aranceles impuestos por el gobierno del presidente Trump, especialmente con México y Canadá, podrían obstaculizar la solución a la crisis en Haití, un tema que la Organización de Estados Americanos (OEA) podría incluir en su agenda.

El canciller norteamericano Marco Rubio, con miras a las elecciones de 2028, está enfocado en resolver la crisis haitiana, donde las bandas criminales afectan al país y a su régimen provisional.

Las dificultades entre Estados Unidos y México por los aranceles y la frontera común, influyen en el desinterés del gobierno de Trump hacia Haití.

La acreditación del nuevo embajador dominicano en México, Juan Bolívar Díaz, podría impulsar que México considere importante la solución del problema haitiano, que hasta ahora ha visto con desinterés.

México y Canadá son miembros de la OEA, pero lidiar con los aranceles de Trump y los problemas fronterizos hacen que la prioridad sea Estados Unidos.

El ministro de relaciones exteriores Rubio, con "línea directa" con el presidente dominicano Abinader, está prestando atención al tema haitiano y a las preocupaciones dominicanas.

La alternativa a la violencia en Haití sería el reforzamiento con tropas a la fuerza de pacificación liderada por Kenia, que no ha podido impedir el crecimiento de las bandas criminales.

La República Dominicana ha puesto en marcha un plan de expulsión de migrantes haitianos sin documentación, lo que ha generado un arma de doble filo al afectar la mano de obra en agricultura y construcción.

Se han levantado opiniones sobre la necesidad de regularizar la fuerza de trabajo haitiana y renovar los permisos laborales para evitar el encarecimiento de construcciones y productos agrícolas, ya que los obreros dominicanos no desean esos trabajos.

El capitán de empresas Frank Rainieri señaló que los trabajadores haitianos realizan trabajos que los dominicanos no quieren, como construcción, servicios domésticos y motoconcho, por lo que rechazar su presencia sin soluciones viables es insuficiente.

title: Trump launches a new trade offensive against Europe
content: On Friday, May 23, the US president threatened to impose 50% tariffs on European products. The 27 member states of the European Union, whose unity remains fragile, have not yet implemented any ...
resumen: On Friday, May 23, 2025, US President Donald Trump threatened to impose 50% tariffs on European products. The partial truce declared by Donald Trump in his trade war with the European Union was set to expire on July 8. Trump said on his social network, Truth Social, "I am recommending a straight 50% Tariff on the European Union, starting on June 1, 2025". He explained that the European Union was formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the United States on TRADE and has been very difficult to deal with. He accused Europeans of "Trade Barriers, Vat Taxes, ridiculous Corporate Penalties, Non-Monetary Trade Barriers, Monetary Manipulations, unfair and unjustified lawsuits against Americans Companies." In the Oval Office, the US president insisted he was not "looking for a deal" with the EU. Trump has denounced European trade surpluses – about €150 billion in industrial goods and €50 billion when accounting for the US surplus in services, according to the European Commission.

title: Clara Mattei, economista: "Con los aranceles, Trump busca dividir a los trabajadores de otros países y unir a sus bases"
content: Clara Mattei, economista: "Con los aranceles, Trump busca dividir a los trabajadores de otros países y unir a sus bases" ...
resumen:
Clara Mattei, economista, afirma que con los aranceles, Trump busca dividir a los trabajadores de otros países y unir a sus bases. Define la austeridad como la forma en que "el dinero y el poder se quedan en manos de muy pocos".

Clara Mattei es profesora de Economía y directora del Centro de Economía Heterodoxa de la Universidad de Tulsa, Oklahoma. Es autora de El orden del capital: cómo los economistas inventaron la austeridad y allanaron el camino hacia el fascismo.

Mattei explica que la austeridad es un medio político y violento de gestionar una sociedad capitalista, y que es crucial para el capitalismo porque proporciona el marco fundamental para subordinar a la mayoría de las personas a su condición de trabajadores asalariados. La austeridad debilita a las personas, las empobrece, hace que dependan más del mercado.

Trump está recortando gastos sociales y cupones de alimentos, mientras reduce los impuestos a las empresas y a la riqueza y propone un aumento en el presupuesto del Pentágono. La militarización es importante para entender su estrategia.

Trump insiste en un mensaje: "Voy a devolver los empleos a los Estados Unidos". Los aranceles lo ponen en la situación de negar el conflicto de costos. Está enfrentando a los trabajadores estadounidenses contra otros trabajadores de otros lugares del mundo, por lo que es una muy buena estrategia para, en última instancia, dividir.

Mattei considera que Trump está intentando afirmar su poder subvirtiendo el orden mundial.

title: Trump tariff tensions test Southeast Asian leaders at regional summit as bloc caught in midst of US-China trade war
content: Southeast Asian leaders will express deep concern over US President Donald Trump's tariff blitz when they meet at a summit Monday, warning that the move poses huge challenges to economic growth and ...
resumen:
Southeast Asian leaders will express deep concern over US President Donald Trump’s tariff blitz when they meet at a summit Monday, warning that the unilateral move poses huge challenges to economic growth and stability in the region, according to a draft statement seen by AFP.

The leaders from the 10-member ASEAN bloc are scrambling for ways to limit the fallout on their trade-dependent economies.

The bloc is also caught between the trade battle between their biggest trading partners, the United States and China, on which Washington has heaped the highest tariffs.

According to a draft statement expected to be issued by ASEAN leaders after they meet on Monday, they express “deep concern… over the imposition of unilateral tariff measures”.

Trump’s measures “pose complex and multidimensional challenges to ASEAN’s economic growth, stability, and integration”, according to the draft of the ASEAN chairman’s statement seen by AFP.

The leaders also “reaffirmed ASEAN’s collective commitment” to the global free trading system, it said.

After the bloc’s meeting on Monday, the leaders are to hold a one-day summit with China and Middle Eastern oil producers.

Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has called for a joint ASEAN action plan to address the growing tariff threat.

Anwar said at a pre-summit briefing that, while bilateral talks between member states and the United States would continue, the bloc must present a united front.

The group, Anwar said, “had very practical policies… and what to me is of critical importance is to build that cohesion within ASEAN”.

The pressure to shift ASEAN’s “friend to all” posture will likely intensify during the follow-up summit on Tuesday when Chinese Premier Li Qiang joins the bloc’s leaders and officials from oil-rich Gulf states.

Beijing has been courting closer ties with Southeast Asia, positioning itself as a “reliable trading partner” despite tensions with ASEAN members over rival claims in the South China Sea.

Li will attend the first-time summit between ASEAN, Beijing and oil-producing nations including Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and Saudi Arabia.

Chinese President Xi Jinping urging greater cooperation between Beijing and Malaysia “to safeguard the bright prospects of our Asian family” during a Southeast Asian diplomatic charm offensive in April.

Anwar said in return that Malaysia would “remain an unwavering and principled friend to China”.

A diplomatic source said that ASEAN countries “won’t automatically fall in China’s arms”.

James Chin, professor of Asian studies at the University of Tasmania, warned that playing to both the United States and China was a “high-risk strategy”.

S. Munirah Alatas, a geopolitics specialist at the University of Malaya’s Allianz Centre for Governance, said the bloc still faced tough unresolved challenges, including “hostilities in Myanmar and recurring tensions in the South China Sea”.

title: Daniel Noboa fue investido para su segundo mandato en Ecuador, en ausencia del correísmo que grita “fraude”
content: El presidente anunció que profundizará su “guerra” contra el crimen organizado, la apertura comercial y las inversiones extranjeras. La izquierda brilló por su ausencia.
resumen:
**El futuro de la colonización:**

*   El 20 de mayo de 2024, se llevó a cabo la primera reunión del Consejo Asesor de la Comisión de Colonización de la Cámara de Representantes.
*   El objetivo principal es analizar el futuro de la colonización en Uruguay.
*   Se busca actualizar la normativa vigente, que data de 1948, para adaptarla a las necesidades actuales.
*   Se abordarán temas como la tenencia de la tierra, el acceso al crédito y la infraestructura.
*   Participaron en la reunión el presidente de la Comisión de Colonización, el diputado Juan Martín Rodríguez, y representantes de diversas instituciones.
*   Entre las instituciones presentes se encontraban el Ministerio de Ganadería, Agricultura y Pesca (MGAP), el Instituto Nacional de Colonización (INC), el Banco de la República Oriental del Uruguay (BROU), la Asociación Rural del Uruguay (ARU), la Federación Rural del Uruguay (FRU), la Comisión Nacional de Fomento Rural (CNFR) y la Federación Uruguaya de Magisterio (FUM).

**Rendición de Cuentas:**

*   El 20 de mayo de 2024, la Comisión de Presupuesto integrada con la de Hacienda de la Cámara de Senadores continuó el análisis del proyecto de Rendición de Cuentas.
*   Se recibieron a representantes de la Administración Nacional de Educación Pública (ANEP).
*   Se discutieron los recursos asignados a la educación y las prioridades del gobierno en este ámbito.

**Aguada vs. Nacional:**

*   El 20 de mayo de 2024, se disputó el tercer partido de la serie de cuartos de final de la Liga Uruguaya de Básquetbol entre Aguada y Nacional.
*   Aguada ganó el partido con un marcador de 88 a 79.
*   Aguada lidera la serie 2 a 1.

**Situación conyugal en Uruguay:**

*   El 20 de mayo de 2024, la Comisión de Constitución y Códigos de la Cámara de Representantes continuó el estudio de un proyecto de ley sobre la situación conyugal en Uruguay.
*   Se busca modificar el Código Civil para actualizar la legislación sobre el matrimonio y el divorcio.
*   Se recibieron a representantes de la Asociación de Magistrados del Uruguay.

title: Bolsa de Valores de Nueva York cae tras anuncio de nuevos aranceles contra la UE
content: Recientemente, cayeron los precios de las acciones en la Bolsa de Valores de Nueva York después de que el presidente de Estados Unidos (EE. UU.), Donald Trump, amenazara con imponer aranceles del 50 ...
resumen: Los precios de las acciones en la Bolsa de Valores de Nueva York cayeron después de que el presidente de Estados Unidos (EE. UU.), Donald Trump, amenazara con imponer aranceles del 50 % a la Unión Europea (UE). El S&P 500 perdió 39,19 puntos, o 0,7 %, para quedar en cinco mil 802,82 y cerrar su peor semana de las últimas siete. El promedio industrial Dow Jones cayó 256,02 puntos, o 0,6 %, y se ubicó en 41 mil 603,07, mientras que el compuesto Nasdaq retrocedió 188,53 unidades, o 1 %, y cerró en 18 mil 737,21. Trump amenazó con los aranceles antes de que abriera el mercado de valores en Estados Unidos, y afirmó en su plataforma Truth Social que las conversaciones comerciales con la Unión Europea “no iban a ninguna parte” y que aranceles “directos del 50 %» podrían entrar en vigor el 1 de junio. La UE es uno de los mayores socios comerciales de Estados Unidos. Las acciones cayeron inmediatamente después en Europa: el índice CAC 40 de Francia perdió 1,7 %. El mercado norteamericano también dio un giro rápido a la baja, y los futuros de los índices bursátiles estadounidenses cayeron después de registrar solo movimientos modestos al inicio de las operaciones. Además, se concretó la venta de bonos del Tesoro por un valor de 16 mil millones que registró una demanda deficiente. Ante esta caída del Wall Street, los bonos del Tesoro alcanzaron mínimos de la sesión después de que la subasta de bonos a 20 años en EE. UU. registrara un rendimiento superior al 5 %.

title: Los excorreístas Marcela Holguín y Fausto Jarrín asistieron a la posesión de Daniel Noboa en la Asamblea
content: La posesión de Daniel Noboa se destacó por la presencia de figuras del correísmo, entre ellas Marcela Holguín.
resumen: El 24 de mayo de 2025, en la Asamblea Nacional en Quito, Ecuador, se realizó la posesión presidencial de Daniel Noboa. Marcela Holguín y Fausto Jarrín, figuras con vínculos con el correísmo, asistieron al evento. La presencia de Marcela Holguín, quien inició su carrera política en 2017 en la Revolución Ciudadana (RC) y fue una voz prominente del movimiento liderado por Rafael Correa, generó atención. Antes de su carrera legislativa, Holguín fue periodista en varios medios televisivos. En las horas previas a la posesión, Holguín fue designada gerente de los medios públicos, lo que generó polémica. Fausto Jarrín, abogado de Rafael Correa en el caso Sobornos, también estuvo presente. Jarrín fue asambleísta entre 2021 y 2022. La asistencia de Holguín y Jarrín contrastó con la decisión de la bancada de la Revolución Ciudadana de no participar en la ceremonia. Otros excorreístas como Ferdinand Álvarez y Soledad Padilla también asistieron. La ceremonia concluyó con el compromiso de Noboa de trabajar por un Ecuador unido y próspero.

title: EE.UU. considera que Daniel Noboa es "incorruptible", señala el Gobierno ecuatoriano
content: Quito, 24 may (EFE).- Estados Unidos considera que Daniel Noboa, presidente de Ecuador, que este sábado juró su nuevo mandato hasta 2029, es "incorruptible", señaló la Presidencia del país andino en u ...
resumen:
Estados Unidos considera que Daniel Noboa, presidente de Ecuador, es “incorruptible”, según el Gobierno ecuatoriano.
Daniel Noboa juró su nuevo mandato hasta 2029.
Tras jurar el cargo, Noboa recibió a representantes de delegaciones internacionales, incluyendo al secretario de Salud y Servicios Humanos de los Estados Unidos, Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
El funcionario estadounidense mencionó que para el Gobierno de Donald Trump, el nuevo periodo presidencial de Noboa será clave para mantener las relaciones bilaterales.
Según un comunicado de la Presidencia, el funcionario estadounidense agregó que “su personalidad, al ser incorruptible, lo destaca como un nuevo líder para el país y en la región”.
Noboa aseveró que su administración se regirá por la transparencia y la lucha contra las mafias del crimen organizado y la corrupción.
Noboa, heredero de una de las mayores fortunas del país, anticipó que defraudará “a las oligarquías que siempre se enriquecían a costa del Estado”.
Noboa, hijo del magnate del sector bananero y cinco veces candidato presidencial Álvaro Noboa, dijo que se creará “un ambiente seguro, estable y competitivo que protege las inversiones y garantiza oportunidades reales”.
En los encuentros de Noboa con los delegados internacionales, se reforzaron lazos de amistad, cooperación y compromiso para defender la democracia en la región y mantener la apertura comercial en beneficio de Ecuador y naciones cooperantes, indicó la Presidencia.
La presidenta de Perú, Dilma Boluarte, felicitó a Noboa por iniciar su segundo mandato presidencial.
Noboa recibió a Thani bin Ahmed Al Zeyoudi, ministro de Comercio de Emiratos Árabes Unidos, para dialogar sobre oportunidades de inversión en Ecuador.
El presidente recibió a la delegación de República Dominicana.

title: Mapfre recompone el negocio y adelanta en Bolsa al sector europeo
content: La acción se acerca al récord con una ganancia acumulada del 40% en el año. El 50% de los analistas recomienda comprar ...
resumen:
Mapfre se revaloriza un 40% en el año, la más alta de las aseguradoras europeas.
Desde julio de 2022 se ha revalorizado el 131% –frente al 70% del Stoxx Insurance– y avanza hacia el récord de 2007.
En el primer trimestre de 2025, Mapfre ganó un 27% más.
La empresa anunció en la junta de accionistas una revisión al alza de la rentabilidad sobre fondos propios (ROE) para los dos próximos años hasta el 11% y 12%, y la ratio combinado lo situó entre el 94% y 95%.
Bestinver Securities apoya su decisión en “la fuerte recuperación de la ratio combinado de Iberia (pasó del 99,7% de 2024 al 95,6% y supuso el 28,5% de las primas del primer trimestre), junto con los mensajes positivos sobre Estados Unidos y Brasil (8,7% y 15% de las primas).
El analista de Bestinver Securities, Javier Beldarrain, ha mejorado el resultado un 22% para 2025 y 2026 (1.162 y 1,230 millones de euros) y el 16% para 2027 (1.256 millones).
Beldarrain acaba de elevar un 25% el precio objetivo, hasta 3,9 euros, el 12% más.
Divacons Alphavalue ha tomado la decisión de elevar las previsiones y la recomendación a añadir.
Los expertos advierten que podría surgir cierta volatilidad en los beneficios debido a Mapfre Re.
Para Ignacio Albizuri, director de mercados de Miraltabank, el camino ascendente de Mapfre se está producido por un cambio de escenario.
Mapfre mantiene el apoyo de los analistas con el 50% de los consejos de compra y el 21,4% de mantener, aunque las de venta alcanzan el 28,6%.
Fitch ha dado apoyo a la compañía al elevar la perspectiva del rating de estable a positiva.
El precio objetivo recogido por Bloomberg de 3,08 euros está por debajo de la cotización.
Bankinter tiene la recomendación de comprar, por “la atractiva rentabilidad por dividendo” (4,6%) y por los múltiplos de valoración, con un PER 2025 de 8,7 veces, frente a las más de 10 veces que presenta el sector en Europa.
El próximo 29 de mayo pagará un dividendo de 0,095 euros.

title: Why Vietnam Ignored Its Own Laws to Fast-Track a Trump Family Golf Complex
content: As President Trump blurs the lines between politics and business — and threatens steep tariffs on trade partners — governments feel compelled to favor Trump-related projects.
resumen:
On Wednesday, a groundbreaking ceremony was held for a Trump golf project in Vietnam. Attendees included Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh, businessman Dang Thanh Tam, and Eric Trump and Lara Trump.

The $1.5 billion golf complex outside Hanoi, as well as plans for a Trump skyscraper in Ho Chi Minh City, are the Trump family’s first projects in Vietnam.

To fast-track the Trump development, Vietnam has ignored its own laws, granting concessions more generous than what even the most connected locals receive. Vietnamese officials explicitly stated that the project required special support from the top ranks of the Vietnamese government because it was “receiving special attention from the Trump administration and President Donald Trump personally.”

Eric Trump was in Vietnam to break ground for the golf project on Wednesday, less than a year after meeting a local building partner, Dang Thanh Tam. Inside a tent with a gold facade, Mr. Trump told guests, including the country’s prime minister, that “the Trump family is going to make you very, very proud.”

President Trump’s financial disclosure report shows that he still personally benefits financially from most of these ventures.

Vietnamese officials say that prioritizing Trump projects assists the country’s economic rise.

With trade negotiations intensifying, Vietnamese officials have allowed the Trump project to break ground without completing at least a half-dozen legally required steps, from securing all the land and financing to conducting environmental reviews.

Initial planning documents were filed only three months before Wednesday’s event, which was held on newly leveled land under an archway announcing “THE GROUNDBREAKING CEREMONY OF TRUMP INTERNATIONAL, HUNG YEN.”

Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh instructed the provincial authorities to ensure that those who sacrificed property would “have a new livelihood and new home better than their old ones.” He also said the project would “receive maximum support” to “further strengthen the relationship between Vietnam and the U.S.” He promised that it would be completed in 2027.

The first Trump project in Vietnam got its start with the efforts of two former Marine Corps platoon commanders: Billy Birdzell and David Lewis.

In January 2024, Birdzell texted “a friend” who was interested in real estate in Vietnam, which was Eric Trump.

Mr. Lewis reached out to Mr. Tam, the founder of the industrial construction firm Kinh Bac City, who embraced the idea immediately.

In a promotional photo from that day, Eric Trump sits on one side, Mr. Tam on the other. The past and future president occupies the center, smiling in front of two American flags.

Vietnam’s government sees Mr. Trump’s administration and the Trump Organization as one.

The groundbreaking occurred just a few days after the Trump administration’s trade negotiator, Jamieson Greer, met with Vietnam’s trade minister, Nguyen Hong Dien, in South Korea.
