title: Trump’s wild tariff tactics risk giving everyone a bad case of burnout
content: Trump threatened a 50% duty on goods coming out of the European Union and a 25% tariff on Apple, sending markets reeling.
resumen: On Friday, Trump threatened a 50% duty on goods coming out of the European Union and a 25% tariff on Apple, sending markets reeling. The prez threatened a 50% duty on goods coming out of the European Union to begin next month, raging that trade discussions “are going nowhere,” and that the EU “was formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the United States on TRADE.” Trump warned Apple that failing to move its manufacturing back home would prompt a tariff of “at least 25%.” In response, the Dow dropped 256 points in a volatile day. Luxury automaker Volvo warned that prices on cars are going to spike. 57% say that tariffs are hurting the economy; 26% think they’re the biggest mistake of Trump’s second term.

title: DOJ and FTC Join Texas AG Paxton in Antitrust Suit Against Asset Giants Over Alleged Coal Market Manipulation
content: DOJ and FTC back Texas AG Paxton's lawsuit alleging collusion by BlackRock, State Street, and Vanguard in the coal market.
resumen: El Departamento de Justicia y la Comisión Federal de Comercio, brazos legales de la administración Trump, se están involucrando en una disputa contra gigantes financieros con el Fiscal General de Texas, Ken Paxton, a la cabeza. En la mira están BlackRock, State Street y Vanguard, acusados de esfuerzos colusorios en el mercado del carbón en busca de agendas de energía verde, a un costo, argumenta Paxton, para la independencia estadounidense y los consumidores. La demanda de Paxton, presentada en noviembre pasado, alega que al aprovechar su considerable influencia en el mercado, los principales administradores de activos conspiraron para reducir a la mitad la producción de carbón para 2030 al servicio de objetivos ambientales. Esta litigación fue reforzada recientemente por la intervención de agencias federales, con el apoyo del Departamento de Justicia y la Comisión Federal de Comercio a la causa de Paxton. El Fiscal General Ken Paxton, agradecido por el apoyo de la administración del expresidente Donald Trump, declaró: "Estoy agradecido de que la Administración Trump se haya unido a mi esfuerzo por responsabilizar a los principales administradores de activos por armar la industria financiera para controlar ilegalmente los mercados energéticos y forzar una destructiva ideología de 'energía verde' en el pueblo estadounidense". Esta demanda afirma que los acusados, a través de su supuesta manipulación, han disparado los costos de la electricidad para los hogares mientras engrosan sus propias arcas financieras. El quid de la cuestión, según Paxton, radica en el uso del poder de mercado para disminuir artificialmente la oferta, lo que desencadena saltos de precios y aprovecha los impulsos políticos bajo la bandera de la lucha contra el cambio climático. Se dice que las tácticas corporativas infringen varias regulaciones estatales y federales que tienen como objetivo prevenir las travesuras anticompetitivas y el comportamiento comercial engañoso. Para la industria del carbón y el sector energético en general, la demanda simboliza un retroceso crítico contra el peso de los inversores institucionales que dirigen las tendencias del mercado bajo la apariencia de inversión socialmente responsable, especialmente en lo que respecta a los recursos energéticos y su costo para los consumidores. "Juntos, el presidente Donald Trump y yo haremos que estas corporaciones rindan cuentas", afirmó el Fiscal General Paxton.

title: Trump firma ordenes ejecutivas para impulsar el desarrollo de la energía nuclear
content: El presidente de EE.UU., Donald Trump, firmó este viernes tres órdenes ejecutivas que buscan impulsar el crecimiento de la energía nuclear en su país, lo ...
resumen: El presidente de EE.UU., Donald Trump, firmó este viernes tres órdenes ejecutivas que buscan impulsar el crecimiento de la energía nuclear en su país, lo que incluye el desarrollo de nuevos tipos de reactores compactos, incrementar la producción de combustible o aumentar las exportaciones del sector. Una de las órdenes busca atajar la futura demanda energética que se espera que tengan en EE.UU. los sectores de inteligencia artificial (IA) y defensa y para ello acelerará los procesos regulatorios para el desarrollo y la adopción de nuevos tipos de unidades de fisión, como los llamados reactores modulares pequeños (SMR por sus siglas en inglés), que aún no tienen uso comercial. Este edicto también crea un puesto de enviado especial para la exportación de tecnología nuclear e insta al Departamento de Energía a aprobar marcos para que aumente el enriquecimiento de uranio en EE.UU., país que obtiene del exterior más de un tercio de su combustible atómico. La segunda orden ejecutiva busca reformar la Comisión Reguladora Nuclear (NRC) para eliminar lo que la Administración Trump considera barreras para la construcción y uso comercial de reactores atómicos «con el objetivo final de cuadruplicar la producción de energía nuclear en las próximas dos décadas y media». A su vez, la tercera orden ejecutiva incluye la invocación de la llamada Ley de Producción de Defensa para impulsar la cooperación con el sector privado de cara a garantizar el futuro suministro de combustible nuclear. Las tres órdenes «permiten realizar pruebas de diseño de reactores en los laboratorios del Departamento de Energía, allanan el camino para la construcción (de plantas) en suelo federal para proteger la seguridad nacional y económica y eliminan las barreras regulatorias al requerir que la NRC emita licencias de manera oportuna», explicó la Casa Blanca en un comunicado posterior.

title: US Stock Market Highlights: US steel surges 21% after Nippon merger approval
content: US stocks fell as Trump targets Apple and EU with tariffs. Dow Jones dropped 181 points, S&P 500 and Nasdaq also fell. Apple shares declined over 2%.
resumen:
US Steel shares soared 21% on Friday after Donald Trump approved its merger with Japan’s Nippon Steel.

US stocks fell on Friday due to renewed trade tensions after President Trump targeted Apple and the EU. The Dow dropped 181 points, S&P 500 and Nasdaq fell 0.4% and 0.7%. Apple shares fell over 2%.

President Donald Trump declared that iPhones sold in the United States must be manufactured domestically—or face a minimum tariff of 25%.

Trump also signalled that trade talks with the EU had stalled, calling for a flat 50% tariff on all EU imports from 1 June 2025.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average shed 181 points, or 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite each dropped 0.4% and 0.7%, respectively.

Tech giant Apple saw its shares fall over 2%.

Following Donald Trump’s renewed trade threats, markets tumbled on Friday.

Booz Allen Hamilton shares tumbled 15% after the consultancy announced plans to cut around 2,500 jobs – 7% of its workforce.

Intuit surged 7.5% after posting strong quarterly results. The firm, which owns TurboTax and QuickBooks, reported a 15% year-on-year revenue rise in its fiscal third quarter, reaching $7.8 billion.

Apple fell 2.6% after President Trump warned the company could face tariffs of 25% or more on iPhones manufactured outside the US.

Apple shares slipped on Friday, pushing its market capitalisation back below the $3 trillion mark.

Three S&P 500 stocks notched fresh record highs: Philip Morris, GE Vernova, and Intuit.

Three names in the index slipped to new 52-week lows: CarMax, Campbell Soup, and Kraft Heinz. Revvity also declined to its lowest since December 2023.

The White House believes financial markets may be overreacting to President Donald Trump’s recent tariff comments.

US new-home sales unexpectedly jumped nearly 11% in April to a 743,000 annual rate.

Chinese EV giant BYD has overtaken Tesla in European battery electric vehicle sales for the first time, despite steeper EU tariffs. April sales surged 359% year-on-year.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average was trading 400 points lower, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite too were trading in the red at 60 and 260 points, respectively, at around 7.04 pm IST.

US-listed shares of Deutsche Bank dropped 5.1%, while HSBC and ING each slipped around 2%. Banco Santander lost 1.9%, and luxury giants LVMH and Hermès also traded lower. The Stoxx Europe 600 index was last down 1.5%.

The yield on the 30-year US Treasury bond reached 5.161% this week, marking its highest level since October 2023. The 10-year note also briefly exceeded 4.6%.

Apple shares dropped 3.5% in premarket trading after President Donald Trump declared the company would face tariffs of 25% or more on iPhones produced outside the US.

Nuclear-related stocks rallied after reports suggested Trump is poised to sign executive orders supporting the sector. Oklo and NuScale each jumped over 8%, while Constellation Energy and Cameco climbed 2% and 4% respectively.

Intuit surged nearly 8% after issuing a strong full-year forecast. The firm now expects adjusted earnings between $20.07 and $20.12 per share.

NuScale, Oklo, Constellation Energy, and Cameco all posted significant gains.

Apple has increased trade-in values for iPhones in China.

The Dow is down 500 points, S&P is at -90 points, and Nasdaq is trading 400 points down.

Donald Trump has proposed a 50% tariff on goods from the European Union.

The Dow is down 500 points, S&P is at -70 points, and Nasdaq is trading 300 points down.

Apple shares dropped 3% in pre-market trading on Friday after US President Donald Trump declared on Truth Social that a 25% tariff “must be paid by Apple” on iPhones sold in the US but manufactured abroad.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average futures dropped 112 points (0.3%), with the Nasdaq 100 and S&P 500 futures also falling 0.4% and 0.3% respectively. Apple shares were caught in the crossfire, down 0.36%.

title: El mercado de las criptomonedas se alista para afrontar el impacto de las tensas negociaciones comerciales globales de Trump.
content: El mercado de las criptomonedas vive momentos de incertidumbre ante las negociaciones tarifarias de Trump Las criptomonedas han experimentado una caída significativa en medio de nuevas tensiones comer ...
resumen: El mercado de las criptomonedas vive momentos de incertidumbre ante las negociaciones tarifarias de Trump. Las criptomonedas han experimentado una caída significativa en medio de nuevas tensiones comerciales entre Estados Unidos y la Unión Europea. La decisión del presidente Donald Trump de proponer aranceles del 50% ha generado nerviosismo en el mercado, repercutiendo en la cotización de activos digitales como Bitcoin y Ethereum. El Bitcoin (BTC), que recientemente alcanzó un máximo histórico de 111,814 dólares, sufrió una caída del 4%, seguida por Ethereum (ETH), que vio una disminución del 3.2% después de que Trump publicara en Truth Social que las negociaciones con la UE «no estaban llevando a ninguna parte». Más de 300 millones de dólares en posiciones apalancadas fueron liquidadas. Trump ha hecho la propuesta de imponer un arancel del 50% sobre las importaciones de la UE, así como un 25% específicamente sobre los iPhones producidos en el extranjero. La expiración de la pausa tarifaria en julio ejerce presión sobre las negociaciones en curso. Ethereum (ETH) no ha escapado a la volatilidad del mercado, manteniendo un nivel de soporte en 2,500 dólares, pero enfrentando dificultades para superar la resistencia de 2,700 dólares, con pérdidas diarias extendiéndose, también, al 4%. La popular criptomoneda Pi Coin mostró signos de crecimiento a principios de este mes, pero no logró sostener sus ganancias después de caer por debajo de 1.23 dólares. Las acciones de empresas tecnológicas en EE.UU. también han reflejado el descenso de las criptomonedas, con Apple experimentando caídas. La implicación personal de Trump en el sector de las criptomonedas ha añadido una capa inesperada de controversia, destacándose en un gálano muy mediático para los principales poseedores del memecoin TRUMP. Tras el gala, el token TRUMP vio un incremento hasta alcanzar los 16 dólares para luego caer a 13.81 dólares.

title: OBBBA & public debt crisis, Faster RBA cuts, Victoria’s debt, US price pressures
content: By Dr Shane Oliver, Chief Economist and Head of Investment Strategy at AMP. Investment markets and key developments Shares were mixed over the last week. US, European and Japanese shares were flat to ...
resumen: Shares were mixed over the last week. US, European and Japanese shares were flat to down slightly after the huge rebound since the April lows left them overbought and as bond yields rose with renewed worries about US public debt sustainability. Chinese shares bucked the trend and rose slightly. Australian shares also rose, with around a 0.3% gain helped by a dovish rate cut from the RBA. Bond yields rose in the US, Europe and Japan but fell slightly in Australia. Oil and iron ore prices fell but with oil bouncing around $US60/barrel and iron ore bouncing around $US100/tonne. Copper prices rose though and gold and Bitcoin also rose with the latter hitting a record high helped by safe haven demand in the face of worries about US debt. Shares have had an impressive rally from their April lows on the back of Trump’s partial tariff pause. US, global and Australian shares recovered more than 80% of their fall into April to be within 2 or 3% of their record high. The fly in the ointment is that macroeconomic risk for shares remains high. US tariffs may be down from their highs but are still five times last year’s levels, they are still likely to go higher for some countries and sectors, hard economic data is still likely to weaken and profit expectations are softening, US policy uncertainty is very high, geopolitical risk is very high particularly with a possible strike on Iran’s nuclear facilities and debate in the US Congress about Trump’s tax cut bill (called the One, Big, Beautiful Bill Act or OBBBA – which has passed the House and going back to the Senate) has renewed concern about US debt. Trump’s policies are increasing the risk of a US debt crisis. Worries about the size of the US budget deficit and public debt have been around for decades with periodic flareups. Higher bond yields are pushing Federal interest payments to a record 18% of tax revenue; debate in Congress about the OBBBA tax cut bill and its impact on debt; Moody’s downgrade of the US credit rating from AAA to Aa1; and concerns about US Treasuries’ safe haven status and US exceptionalism flowing from Trump’s chaos around tariffs, Fed independence, the rule of law, universities, etc. All of which is refocussing concern on ever rising US public debt. US Federal debt is now much higher than it was when S&P downgraded the US credit rating in 2011 and projections by the US Congressional Budget Office indicate that the tax cut bill will keep the budget deficit around 7% of GDP which is well above the 3% or so of GDP necessary to stabilise the debt to GDP ratio. The debt to GDP ratio will keep rising indefinitely. This in turn will mean that net interest costs will rise further into record territory. The falling US dollar suggests foreign investors may be becoming less keen on buying US Treasuries and hence financing ever rising US public debt. The return of the “bond vigilantes” resulting in even higher US bond yields could in turn put pressure on shares by further reducing the already low risk premium they offer over bonds. US gross public debt at around 125% of GDP is below that in Japan but above the average of advanced countries at 110% and well above that in Australia at 50% of GDP. The ride is likely to remain volatile in the months ahead and another leg down remains a high risk. Trump is likely to pivot from the focus on tariffs to tax cuts and deregulation which along with rate cuts from the Fed in the third quarter and other central banks should help shares stage a more sustainable recovery. The RBA cut rates again, from 4.1% to 3.85%, with more cuts ahead. The key messages from the May RBA meeting were that the risks to growth coming from Trump’s trade war are rising threatening higher unemployment, but with inflation back to target and forecast to remain there and monetary policy still being restrictive – with a cash rate of 3.85% against an average of neutral estimates around 2.8% – the RBA is able to cut interest rates and is likely to cut further. The RBA to cut three more times to 3.1% by early next year with cuts in August, November and February, but given the threat to growth and allowing for the RBA’s newfound dovishness, there is a high risk that the cuts come faster and we reach 2.85% by early next year. There is now a good chance that the next cut will come at the July meeting if monthly inflation data for April and May remain benign and the risks out of the US around trade and other things remain high or get worse. The money market now sees about a 65% chance of a 0.25% cut in July and 2.8 cuts by year end. Victoria’s 2025-26 Budget lacked the fiscal restraint necessary to provide confidence that its already high level of debt will come under control. The Government projects a small operating surplus this was only because of a windfall $3.7bn in extra revenue from the GST carve up which then allowed a new spending spree leaving the total budget in deficit through the forward estimates, net public debt still on the rise at a level of GDP well in excess of other states and an ongoing rise in total public sector debt interest payments which are projected to take up around 9.5% of revenue by 2028-29. Victoria already faces borrowing costs around 0.35% to 0.5% pa higher than NSW reflecting its lower AA credit rating compared to NSW’s AAA rating. Another rating downgrade to say AA- could add around 0.1% to 0.2% or so to its borrowing rates and add another $150m to $300m to its net annual interest bill. Aggregate business conditions PMIs in developed countries improved very slightly in May with Japan and Europe down but the US back up helped by Trump’s partial tariff pauses. There was a further rise in input and output price pressures due to increases in the US. The US composite PMI rose to an okay reading of 52.1 in May, the tariffs are still leading to a sharp rise in US input and output price pressures. Jobless claims remained low suggesting the labour market is still okay. The leading indicators index for April fell more than expected with annual growth becoming more negative again warning that recession risk is intensifying again. Existing home sales rose, but they are just bouncing around low levels. UK inflation in April rose more than expected to 3.5%yoy from 2.6%yoy mainly due to higher administered utility prices which also pushed up core inflation to 3.8%yoy from 3.4%yoy. Canadian inflation for April also fell less than expected to 1.7%yoy with core trimmed mean inflation rising 3.1%yoy. Japanese inflation remained at 3.6%yoy in April reflecting sharp rises in energy and food prices with core (ex-energy and food) inflation stable at 1.6%yoy. Chinese retail sales, industrial production and investment were a bit softer than expected in April but the trend in growth

title: Ray Dalio Says Trump Tariffs Are Fueling a New Global Order Without US
content: As international deals bypass the U.S. and deficits surge, Ray Dalio warns the country is losing its place in the global economic order.
resumen:
Ray Dalio says tariffs are driving global growth away from the U.S. while rising deficits threaten economic stability.
Ray Dalio, founder of Bridgewater Associates, is sounding the alarm over the Trump administration’s global tariff policies, warning they could reshape the world economy to America’s disadvantage.
Dalio said the tariffs are accelerating international dealmaking that increasingly bypasses the U.S.
Dalio noted a rising trend in cross-border agreements that exclude the U.S.
Dalio founded Bridgewater Associates nearly 50 years ago and built it into one of the largest hedge funds globally, managing $92.1 billion in assets as of last year.
He stepped down as CEO in 2017 but remains a prominent voice in finance, with an estimated net worth of $14 billion.
Dalio’s concerns extend beyond trade policy to America’s fiscal health, particularly the ballooning federal deficit.
He said, “We will have a deficit of about 6.5 percent of GDP—that is more than the market can bear,” pointing to rising long-term bond yields as a red flag.
The national debt is set to rise further following the passage of President Donald Trump’s sweeping tax-cut bill, dubbed the ‘One Big Beautiful Bill Act,’ which cleared the House on May 22.
According to Dalio, meaningful deficit reduction won’t be addressed until after the 2026 midterm elections, when a bipartisan committee is expected to take up the issue.

resumen: Ecuador espera cerrar en junio la negociación con Estados Unidos sobre un acuerdo que revierta el 10 % de arancel que impuso el presidente Donald Trump a los productos ecuatorianos. El sector bananero tenÃ­a 0 % arancel y con la decisiÃ³n de Estados Unidos subiÃ³ a 10%, igual que el camarÃ³n. El sector pesquero que tenÃ­a aranceles de hasta el 35 % subiÃ³ al 45 %. title: Trump abandona a Europa.
content: De agresor a mediador. Los señores de la guerra que forman parte de la OTAN-EU se han quedado sin su principal promotor de la guerra proxy Rusia-Ucrania, su socio, Estados Unidos, representado por el ...
resumen:
Donald Trump, el nuevo presidente de Estados Unidos, ha transformado la política de su país de ser agresor a mediador, abandonando a Europa y a la OTAN en su propósito de derrotar militarmente a Rusia.

Trump ha manifestado que la guerra que empezó "el estúpido presidente Joe Biden" no es su guerra, que su agenda tiene otras prioridades y objetivos estratégicos para hacer más grande a Estados Unidos, que no va a jugar a la guerra poniendo al mundo al borde de una guerra nuclear, y que hay que pagarle la inversión norteamericana en la guerra mediante un contrato de explotación y manejo de las tierras raras.

También ha declarado que Ucrania jamás pertenecerá a la OTAN, que la Unión Europea tiene que asumir su propia defensa gastando el 5% del PIB en armas para su seguridad, y que Europa tiene que equilibrar su balanza de pagos, o impondrá aranceles prohibitivos.

Trump ha ordenado el desmantelamiento de la USAID, un brazo político de la CIA, especialista en aplicar golpe suave a través de revoluciones de colores y la Primavera Árabe, y espera un acuerdo de paz que le permita hacer negocio con Rusia, en la explotación de las tierras raras de Ucrania, del Ártico y de recursos naturales de la Federación Rusa.

title: Stock market today: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq fall as Trump tariff threats roar back, US deficit anxiety deepens
content: Wall Street is assessing President Trump''s tariff salvo on Apple and what his giant tax bill means for the deficit and the economy.
resumen:
US stocks fell on Friday to register weekly losses. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) sank 0.6%. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) also fell roughly 0.7%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) backed off about 1%. All three major averages fell more than 2% for the week. The three indexes trimmed steeper losses that followed Trump's comment on Friday that Apple (AAPL) must pay a 25% tariff on iPhones sold but not made in the US. Apple shares fell about 3%. Trump implied the tariffs would apply to other cell phone manufacturers. Trump threatened to hike the tariff on EU imports to "a straight 50%" beginning June 1. The president's warnings shattered a more muted mood on Wall Street as investors wound down to the Memorial Day trading break on Monday. Stocks have suffered this week as deficit worries pushed up Treasury yields. The 30-year yield (^TYX) eased but held above the key level of 5% on Friday. Wall Street's attention has also begun to turn to Nvidia (NVDA) earnings, due Wednesday after the bell.

Stocks closed out the week in the red on Friday as renewed threats from President Trump against the European Union and iPhone maker Apple (AAPL) reignited concerns that the trade war is far from over. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) sank 0.3% for the session, but was down more than 2% for the week. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) and tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) also registered weekly losses of more than 2%. Shares of US Steel (X) skyrocketed more than 20% in the last half hour of trading on Friday after President Trump announced the American company will form a partnership with Nippon Steel of Japan. Apple shares fell nearly 3% after President Trump said the company must pay at least a 25% tariff unless iPhones sold in the US are manufactured domestically. Trump also threatened to hike tariffs on EU imports to "a straight 50%" beginning June 1. The market slumped this week as 10-year and 30-year Treasury bond prices declined.

Next week's trading will be shortened due to Memorial Day. The stock market will be closed on Monday. The big focus next week will be on Nvidia (NVDA). The AI chip giant will report its earnings on Wednesday, after the bell.

President Trump reiterated his demand that Apple (AAPL) — and potentially other smartphone manufacturers — produce devices in the United States if they intend to sell them domestically. Otherwise, they could face tariffs. Apple (AAPL) stock fell more than 2% mid-morning Friday after President Trump said the company faces at least a 25% tariff, unless its iPhones sold in the US are made domestically. Tesla (TSLA), Meta (META), Alphabet (GOOGL, GOOG), Amazon (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT), and Nvidia (NVDA) all declined roughly 1% during the session.

Nuclear stocks rallied after President Trump signed executive orders to revive the industry. Nuclear-related stocks Oklo (OKLO), Constellation Energy (CEG), and Nano Nuclear (NNE) all rose by double-digit percentages.

Solar stocks rebounded on Friday but were still on track to close out the week with steep losses. SolarEdge (SEDG), Sunrun (RUN), Complete Solaria (SPWR), and Enphase Energy (ENPH) were among the biggest decliners this week, all down double-digit percentages.

Bitcoin (BTC-USD) dropped nearly 2% from its recent record high to hover near $109,000. Crypto-related stocks also sank on Friday. Shares of Strategy (MSTR) dropped more than 3%. Mara Holdings (MARA) and Riot Platforms (RIOT) dropped more than 5% and 3%, respectively.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) sank 1%, or over 400 points. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) fell 1.3%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) backed off 1.2%. Apple shares sank after Trump said the iPhone maker would face at least 25% tariffs if it did not make its iPhones sold in the US domestically. He also threatened to hike the tariff on EU imports to "a straight 50%" beginning June 1.

Volvo Cars (VOLCAR-B.ST) warned that it's customers may have to pay a large part of the company's tariff related cost increases. Shares in the company fell over 4%.

Europe's broad Stoxx (^STOXX) 600 index fell as much as 2% before recouping some of those losses.

Futures on the Dow Jones Industrial Average (YM=F) dropped 1.4%, or nearly 600 points, while those tied to the S&P 500 (ES=F) fell 1.6%. Contracts on the tech-heavy Nasdaq 100 (NQ=F) sank 1.9%.

Shares of nuclear power companies soared in premarket after Reuters reported that President Trump will soon sign executive orders aimed at jump-starting the nuclear energy industry. Shares of Oklo (OKLO), a nuclear start-up backed by OpenAI's Sam Altman, surged 19%. Other big gainers included Nano Nuclear Energy (NNE) and NuScale Power (SMR), both up around 17%. Among nuclear utilities, Constellation Energy (CEG) put on 5%, Vistra (VST) gained 4%, and GE Vernova (GEV) added 3%.

Deckers Outdoor (DECK) said late Thursday it won't provide annual guidance because of uncertainty around the economic impact of US tariffs. The maker of Hoka and UGG footwear also posted a disappointing quarterly sales forecast, helping drive its shares 17% lower in premarket.

The yield on the 30-year Treasury (^TYX) has risen above 5%.

title: European plastics industry could suffer under Trump's threatened 50% tariffs
content: Plastics machinery could be "collateral damage" in a trade war between the United States and the European Union under new tariffs proposed to start June 1.
resumen:
President Donald Trump is threatening a straight 50 percent tariff on goods from the European Union starting June 1.

Trump said trade talks with the EU, which covers 27 member countries, aren't going anywhere in a May 23 post on his Truth Social network.

Trump posted that the EU was formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the United States on TRADE, and that the EU has trade barriers, Vat Taxes, ridiculous Corporate Penalties, Non-Monetary Trade Barriers, Monetary Manipulations, unfair and unjustified lawsuits against Americans Companies, and more, have led to a Trade Deficit with the U.S. of more than $250,000,000 a year.

Plastics News' Economics Editor Bill Wood noted that the trade deficit with the EU is closer to $250 billion than the $250 million in Trump's post — and that the U.S. has a trade deficit when it comes to plastics machinery.

Perc Pineda, chief economist of the Plastics Industry Association in Washington, said that imposing high tariffs on manufacturing inputs could raise production costs and hinder domestic manufacturing competitiveness in the near term.

Pineda said that for machinery that is no longer produced domestically, tariff rates should remain low.

The U.S. is the largest export region and investment location outside of Europe for the VDMA, a mechanical engineering industry association based in Germany with 3,600 members in Europe.

VDMA Chief Economist Johannes Gernandt said that the current blanket import tariffs of 10 percent on almost all product groups — including machinery and equipment — announced by the U.S. government in early April already was causing additional uncertainty in foreign trade.

Gernandt said that the USA is their largest single market and that new trade barriers come at an inopportune time.

Gernandt appealed to politicians to keep markets open.

Pineda said European companies should consider increasing value-added activities within the U.S. rather than relying solely on exports and distribution.

Wood said that a reset between the U.S. and its trade partners is long overdue.

title: Pro-Trump TV Ad Overstates His Second-Term Economic Record
content: A TV ad from a group supportive of President Donald Trump makes misleading claims, and uses outdated data, to argue that he is "fixing" an economy "ruined" by Democrats.
resumen:
A TV ad from a group supportive of President Donald Trump makes misleading claims, and uses outdated data, to argue that he is “fixing” an economy “ruined” by Democrats.

The ad says that “inflation and gas prices” are now “at four-year lows,” based on data from March. National average gasoline prices have increased since then and are several cents higher than when Trump took office. Economists have warned that inflation also may soon increase again because of Trump’s tariff policies.

The ad also says that “Trump’s plan” is to provide “middle-class tax cuts.” The Republican budget bill would benefit middle-income taxpayers by extending the 2017 tax cuts — on average, every income group would get some tax relief. However, a nonpartisan tax policy organization has found that the majority of the tax cut benefits would go to the wealthiest 20% of households.

Securing American Greatness, the nonprofit group behind the 30-second ad, paid in the “high seven figures” to run the commercial for two weeks in 20 targeted congressional districts nationwide, on cable TV and online. The ad started airing May 12.

The ad begins with a narrator saying that “they’ve ruined our economy,” as photos of Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, Rep. Nancy Pelosi and former President Joe Biden, all Democrats, are shown on screen. “President Trump is fixing it,” the narrator later says.

The economy wasn’t the best it’s ever been when Trump took office again in January – but it also wasn’t in ruin. Trump inherited an economy experiencing significant annual growth, monthly job and stock market gains, plus much lower inflation than in 2022. Gary Cohn, director of the White House National Economic Council during Trump’s first term, said in a December interview on “Face the Nation” that Trump was inheriting from Biden a “very stable economy.”

The ad’s narrator mentions “middle-class tax cuts.” The House-passed budget reconciliation bill would reduce taxes for middle-income households compared with what they would pay if the individual income tax cuts in a 2017 tax law are allowed to expire at the end of the year.

“Middle-income households would receive an average tax cut of about $1,800, or about 2.4 percent of their after-tax income,” according to Tax Policy Center estimates. Those households have incomes between about $66,800 and $119,200.

The TPC also found that “60 percent of the tax cuts would go to the top 20 percent of households and more than one-third would go to those making $460,000 or more.” The “biggest beneficiaries,” the TPC said, would be households making between $460,000 and $1.1 million, whose taxes would be reduced by an average of nearly $21,000, or 4.3% of their after-tax income.

The bottom 20% of households, who make about $35,000 or less, would get a tax cut of less than 1%, or about $160 on average.

An analysis of the budget bill by the Penn Wharton Budget Model says that the benefits disparity is even larger when factoring in the bill’s cuts to safety net programs like Medicaid and supplemental food assistance. According to PWBM, even when considering the bill’s tax relief, in the long-term “lower-income households and some in the middle class are worse off, despite positive economic effects.” The top 10% of the income distribution receives about 70 percent of the total value of the legislation.

The narrator of the ad claims that “we’re already seeing results” from Trump’s economic plan, as text on screen says “Trump’s Tariffs … Delivered Results.”

The quote attributed to the New York Times isn’t about results for the economy. The March 5 story highlighted in the ad was about tariffs that Trump announced this year on imports of Mexican goods that got Mexico to produce results for the U.S. on illegal immigration and fentanyl smuggling.

The Times reported that “Sheinbaum dispatched thousands of National Guard troops to the state of Sinaloa, the hub of fentanyl trafficking, where they seized vast amounts of the synthetic opioid and busted hundreds of laboratories.” Then she “sent thousands more” troops to the U.S. border, “contributing to a plunge in the number of illegal crossings,” the story said.

Mexico had “agreed to send more than two dozen alleged cartel heads to be tried in the United States,” reversing the Mexican government’s position on extraditions.

The ad’s narrator says that “the cost of living is coming down,” adding that “inflation and gas prices [are] at four-year lows.”

The ad refers to core inflation, which is a measure of the change in the price of goods excluding food and energy items. The April 10 Forbes article cited in the ad reported that the annual rate of core inflation was 2.8% in March, the lowest since March 2021. Core CPI was also 2.8% in April, the most recent data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The same Forbes article noted that tariffs that Trump implemented in early April, and ones that are currently on a 90-day pause, could end up increasing inflation again. It said that “Goldman forecasted the core CPI rate,” influenced by Trump’s tariffs, “would jump to 3.7% by the end of 2025, which would be a level not seen since March 2024.”

Average prices for regular gasoline are not at a four-year low. The claim appears to be based on a March 13 Inc article. Inc reported that average retail gasoline prices in early March “slid to a multi-year low, according to GasBuddy data.” At the time, GasBuddy, which tracks fuel prices, said that the national average cost had fallen to about $3.03 per gallon, “the lowest March level since the pandemic.”

As of the week ending May 19, the average price of gasoline nationally was about $3.17 per gallon, according to the Energy Information Administration. That was up from about $3.11 when Trump took office, according to EIA figures.

The ad’s narrator says “wages are up” while viewers see the words “hourly earnings increased,” which is a quote from the April 4 CNBC article cited in the ad.

CNBC reported that the one-month increase in average hourly earnings for private workers was 0.3% in March, the news outlet said that the annualized growth rate of 3.8% was the lowest level since July 2024. Then average hourly earnings increased 0.2% month over month in April, and, again, the year-over-year increase was 3.8%, according to the BLS.

As of April, average hourly earnings had increased 0.6% since Trump took office again.

The

title: Apple has had few incentives till now to start making iPhones in the United States
content: It would take several years and cost billions of dollars to build plants in the United States to make iPhones here. If that happens, prices could skyrocket.
resumen:
Apple has had few incentives till now to start making iPhones in the United States.
It would take several years and cost billions of dollars to build plants in the United States to make iPhones here.
If that happens, prices could skyrocket.
President Donald Trump threatened Friday to slap a 25% tariff on the popular device unless the tech giant starts building the product in its home country.
Apple has been building most of its devices in China, where it has invested tens of billions of dollars in massive factories that rely on a vast network of local suppliers.
Apple CEO Tim Cook said this month that most iPhones sold in the United States during March through June would come from India.
Cook said the trade war would end up costing the company an additional $900 million during the March-June period.
Industry analysts estimated the fees would drive up the cost of a $1,200 iPhone made in China to $1,500.
If Apple somehow could suddenly start making iPhones in the United States, prices for the devices would soar to at least $2,000 and possibly as high as $3,500.
The disincentives for Apple shifting its production domestically include a complex supply chain that Cook began to engineer in the 1990s while working for his predecessor, company co-founder Steve Jobs, who died in 2011.
It would take several years and cost billions of dollars to build plants in the United States.
The price of an iPhone could triple, threatening to torpedo sales of Apple’s marquee product, which brought revenue of $201 billion during the company’s latest fiscal year.
Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives estimated that the current $1,000 price tag for an iPhone made in China, or one made in India, would soar to more than $3,000 if production shifts to the United States.
Moving production domestically likely couldn’t be done until, at the earliest, 2028.
Ives predicted that Cook would engage in a “game of negotiations” with Trump that would spare the iPhone from the 25% tariffs.
As AI becomes more sophisticated, the technology might spawn a wave of hands-free and screen-free devices that lower demand for smartphones.
Apple executive Eddy Cue said this month during a trial about the Justice Department’s proposed breakup of Google for running an illegal monopoly in search, “You may not need an iPhone 10 years from now, as crazy as it sounds.”
Cook told investors tariffs had a “limited impact” on the company in the March quarter because Apple was able to optimize its supply chain.
Cook warned that it is “very difficult” to predict beyond June “because I’m not sure what will happen with tariffs.”
Many analysts are predicting Apple will raise iPhone prices come fall, when the latest models are typically released.
Apple continues to reap huge profit margins from the revenue generated by subscriptions and other services tied to its product, according to Forrester Research analyst Dipanjan Chatterjee.
That division collected $96 billion in revenue during Apple’s last fiscal year.
Apple can absorb some of the tariff-induced cost increases without significant financial impact, at least in the short term.
Apple is facing a significant decline in its service revenue after a federal judge recently issued an order prohibiting it from collecting commissions on transactions within iPhone apps that are processed on other payment systems other than its own.
Unless Apple prevails in an appeal, the decision could cost the company billions of dollars a year.

title: Trump threatens EU, Apple with tariffs over major gripe
content: Donald Trump has reignited his trade war with Europe — recommending a 50 per cent tariff on all goods — with the complaint that negotiations have been "going nowhere".
resumen:
El 29 de mayo de 2024, el Consejo de Ministros aprobó el proyecto de Ley de Eficiencia del Sector Público, que busca mejorar la gestión y el funcionamiento de las administraciones públicas. La ley se estructura en tres títulos:

*   **Título I: Medidas de eficiencia organizativa.** Incluye la creación de la Oficina Nacional de Supervisión y Evaluación de la Gestión Pública, que evaluará el desempeño de las entidades del sector público. También se promueve la simplificación administrativa y la colaboración entre administraciones.
*   **Título II: Medidas de eficiencia en la gestión de los recursos humanos.** Se establecen mecanismos para optimizar la planificación de plantillas y la gestión del talento en el sector público.
*   **Título III: Medidas de eficiencia en la gestión económica y financiera.** Se busca mejorar la gestión presupuestaria, la contratación pública y la utilización de los fondos europeos.

La ley se enviará al Congreso de los Diputados para su tramitación parlamentaria.

title: Trump’s tariff threats clash with Apple iPhone's global supply chain reality
content: Trump told reporters later on Friday that the 25% tariff would also apply to Samsung 005930.KS and other smartphone makers.
resumen: President Donald Trump threatened on Friday to impose a 25% tariff on Apple for any iPhones sold, but not made, in the United States, as part of his administration's goal of re-shoring jobs. He expects the tariffs to go into effect at the end of June. The 25% tariff would also apply to Samsung and other smartphone makers. Trump had an understanding with Apple CEO Tim Cook that he wouldn't be doing this. Cook said he's going to India to build plants. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said the work of "millions and millions of human beings screwing in little, little screws to make iPhones" would come to the United States and be automated, creating jobs for skilled trade workers such as mechanics and electricians. Lutnick said Cook told him that doing so requires technology not yet available. Dan Ives, an analyst at Wedbush, said moving production to the United States could take up to a decade and could result in iPhones costing $3,500 each. Apple's top-of-the-line iPhone currently retails for around $1,200. Brett House, an economics professor at Columbia, said a tariff on iPhones would increase consumer costs by complicating Apple's supply chain and financing. Sally Stewart Laing, a partner at Akin Gump in Washington, said there's no clear legal authority that permits company-specific tariffs, but the Trump administration may try to shoehorn it under its emergency power authorities. Tim Meyer, an international law professor at Duke University, said in the administration's view, as long as he enacts the ritual of declaring an emergency and pronouncing it unusual or extraordinary, there is nothing a court can do.

title: ‘There Is No Tariff’: Trump Denies Policy Shift After Calling for 50% EU Tariff
content: Just hours after President Donald Trump called for a 50% tariff on products from the European Union starting June 1, he told reporters “There is no tariff,” and “I’m not looking for a deal.” “The ...
resumen: President Donald Trump called for a 50% tariff on products from the European Union starting June 1, but later said “There is no tariff,” and “I’m not looking for a deal.” Trump wrote on Truth Social at 7:43 AM that the European Union has been difficult to deal with, citing trade barriers, VAT taxes, corporate penalties, non-monetary trade barriers, monetary manipulations, and lawsuits against American companies, leading to a trade deficit with the U.S. of more than $250,000,000 a year. He recommended a 50% Tariff on the European Union, starting on June 1, 2025, but there is no Tariff if the product is built or manufactured in the United States. A reporter asked Trump what he was hoping to achieve with a 50% tariff, to which Trump responded, “There is no tariff. What they will do is they will send their companies into the US.” Trump also stated, “I’m not looking for a deal. We’ve set the deal at 50%.”

title: Trump amenaza con nuevos aranceles a la UE y a los fabricantes de celulares
content: El presidente de EE.UU. planea imponer tarifas de hasta 50% a productos de la Unión Europea, a partir del 1 de junio; y del 25% a empresas Apple y Samsung ...
resumen:
El presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, renovó su ofensiva comercial con amenazas de aranceles de hasta 50% a los productos de la Unión Europea y del 25% a empresas de tecnología como Apple y Samsung.

Trump anunció en su red Truth Social que recomienda "imponer 50% de aranceles a la Unión Europea a partir del 1 de junio".

Los aranceles actuales están situados en una media de 12.5% (2.5% ya vigentes antes de la investidura de Trump y un 10% adicional desde abril de este año).

Trump denunció el déficit comercial de Estados Unidos con Europa, que estima entre 300,000 y 350,000 millones de dólares.

Según los datos del representante de la Casa Blanca para Comercio, el déficit comercial de Estados Unidos con el bloque europeo se elevó a 235,000 millones de dólares en 2024.

La Comisión Europea cuestiona esas cifras y habla de 150,000 millones de euros (unos $160,000 millones), y únicamente 50,000 millones de euros si se integra el excedente comercial estadounidense en términos de servicios.

Trump dijo que pese a sus reiterados pedidos, Apple no había trasladado la fabricación de sus iPhones a Estados Unidos, y amenazó con aplicarle a la empresa un arancel de "al menos" 25% si no nacionaliza la producción.

Trump amenazó con aplicar el arancel a la surcoreana Samsung y a otros fabricantes de móviles, si no mueven su producción a territorio estadounidense.

Apple se dispone a ampliar su cadena de suministro en la India a través de la construcción de una nueva planta valorada en 1,500 millones de dólares por parte de la taiwanesa Foxconn, su principal ensambladora, en medio de la guerra comercial entre Estados Unidos y China.

Las acciones de Apple perdían un 2.7% en los primeros intercambios.

Trump amenazó con imponer aranceles de al menos 10% a la mayoría de los productos que ingresan a Estados Unidos.

title: Estados Unidos espera que advertencia de Trump impulse diálogo comercial con la Unión Europea
content: El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, expresó su confianza en que la advertencia de Donald Trump, sobre imponer un arancel del 50% a los productos importados desde la Unión Europe ...
resumen:
El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, afirmó que espera que la advertencia de Donald Trump, sobre imponer un arancel del 50% a los productos importados desde los Veintisiete, “encienda una llama” que acelere las negociaciones.

Bessent afirmó que la Unión Europea “tiene un problema de acción colectiva” pues 27 países están representados por la Comisión Europea. Añadió que algunos de los países “ni siquiera saben qué está negociando la Unión Europea en su nombre”.

En cuanto a las negociaciones, el secretario del Tesoro estadounidense afirmó que las propuestas de la Unión Europea “no han sido de la misma calidad” que las planteadas por otros socios comerciales importantes, añadiendo que la amenaza de Trump responde simplemente “al ritmo de la Unión Europea”.

Bessent destacó que hay “18 acuerdos comerciales importantes que debemos cerrar”, trabajando principalmente en Asia, después de haber cerrado el acuerdo con Reino Unido. “Creo que habrá un par más próximamente”, anticipó.

“Muchos países asiáticos han llegado con muy buenos acuerdos, así que hay 18 socios comerciales importantes, y diría que, con la excepción de la Unión Europea, la mayoría está negociando de muy buena fe”, resumió Bessent.

El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, recomendó imponer un arancel del 50% a los productos procedentes de la Unión Europea a partir del próximo 1.º de junio de 2025, al considerar que las negociaciones comerciales con el bloque “no van a ninguna parte”.

Trump anunció a través de su perfil en Truth Social que “no se aplicará ningún arancel si el producto se fabrica en Estados Unidos”.

title: Aranceles a Apple también van contra Samsung y otros fabricantes de smartphones: Trump
content: Tras amenazar con aranceles del 25% a Apple, Trump dijo que la medida se extenderá a fabricantes de smartphones que produzcan fuera de EU, como Samsung.
resumen: Tras amenazar con aranceles del 25% a Apple, Trump dijo que la medida se extenderá a fabricantes de smartphones que produzcan fuera de Estados Unidos, como Samsung. El presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, intensificó este viernes su presión sobre los principales fabricantes de teléfonos inteligentes, al advertir que impondrá aranceles del 25% a todas las compañías que produzcan fuera de Estados Unidos, incluyendo a Apple y Samsung. Durante una aparición en la Casa Blanca, Trump explicó que los nuevos aranceles no se limitarán a Apple, sino que también alcanzarán a “Samsung y cualquiera que fabrique ese producto”, en referencia a los teléfonos inteligentes ensamblados en el extranjero. Trump señaló que estas medidas comenzarían a aplicarse a finales de junio, como parte de su estrategia para forzar a las compañías tecnológicas a relocalizar su producción en territorio estadounidense. Horas antes, en una publicación en Truth Social, Trump ya había amenazado con imponer un arancel del 25% a los iPhone fabricados fuera del país, si Apple no trasladaba sus operaciones desde el extranjero a Estados Unidos. Sus declaraciones posteriores en el Despacho Oval confirmaron que la medida también incluiría a otros gigantes del sector, como la surcoreana Samsung Electronics. “Cualquiera que fabrique ese producto fuera del país deberá pagar”, reiteró Trump, reforzando su mensaje de reindustrialización nacional y protección del empleo local. La propuesta representa un nuevo episodio en la política comercial del presidente, caracterizada por el uso de aranceles como herramienta de presión sobre empresas extranjeras y estadounidenses que operan fuera de las fronteras. Aunque Apple ha aumentado su inversión en Estados Unidos en los últimos años, la mayor parte de sus productos —incluido el iPhone— sigue fabricándose en China y otros países asiáticos. Samsung, por su parte, produce gran parte de sus dispositivos en Corea del Sur, Vietnam y la India. Los analistas advierten que este tipo de medidas podría tener efectos negativos para los consumidores, al encarecer los productos tecnológicos y alimentar una nueva ola de tensiones comerciales, especialmente con países asiáticos clave para la cadena de suministro global. La amenaza de Trump también se produce en un contexto político más amplio, donde busca reafirmar su agenda económica nacionalista de cara al ciclo electoral, apelando al discurso de “traer los empleos de vuelta a casa”. Mientras tanto, las acciones de Apple caían 2.75% a menos de una hora del cierre del mercado.

title: Costa Rica destaca logros tras 4 años en la OCDE y apunta a un mayor liderazgo
content: San José, 23 may (EFE).- Costa Rica cumple cuatro años como integrante de la Organización para la Cooperación y el Desarrollo Económicos (OCDE) con la mirada puesta en ejercer un papel de más liderazg ...
resumen:
Costa Rica cumple cuatro años como integrante de la Organización para la Cooperación y el Desarrollo Económicos (OCDE) con la mirada puesta en ejercer un papel de más liderazgo y de compartir sus experiencias en ámbitos como el comercio, el medio ambiente, el turismo y la atracción de inversiones.

El ministro de Comercio Exterior de Costa Rica, Manuel Tovar, dijo que Costa Rica da un paso adelante para liderar y que hay confianza en Costa Rica y una estrecha relación con todos los países.

El 25 de mayo de 2021 Costa Rica se convirtió en el cuarto país latinoamericano en ingresar a la OCDE -tras México, Chile y Colombia- y después de un proceso de adhesión que se extendió por 9 años y que requirió la aprobación de 22 comités de la organización.

El ministro Tovar afirmó que es un “honor” para Costa Rica formar parte de la OCDE pero también una “gran responsabilidad” que requiere una “evaluación continua” de las políticas públicas del país.

Costa Rica presidirá el próximo 3 y 4 de junio la Reunión del Consejo Ministerial de la OCDE en París, bajo el lema 'Liderando el camino hacia una prosperidad resiliente, inclusiva y sostenible a través del comercio basado en normas, la inversión y la innovación'.

Entre los objetivos de este encuentro sobresalen reforzar los mercados abiertos y un sistema de comercio internacional basado en normas; impulsar la economía digital para conseguir un crecimiento en favor de una prosperidad compartida; y fomentar un crecimiento económico sostenible e inclusivo mediante políticas innovadoras.

Tovar comentó que Costa Rica quiere promover varias acciones específicas encaminadas a estándares internacionales para regular la gobernanza de la inteligencia artificial.

En materia comercial “recalcar la importancia de un sistema internacional basado en reglas, abordar temas relevantes como seguridad económica, de las cadenas de suministros, evitar distorsiones de mercado; la seguridad energética mundial y las energías limpias”, dijo el ministro.

Otro objetivo será trabajar en un “marco estratégico de colaboración” de la OCDE con Latinoamérica y el Caribe para compartir experiencias positivas en modelos de reformas estructurales de los países.

El ministro destacó que durante los 4 años en la OCDE, Costa Rica conseguido implementar reformas en diversas áreas como el comercio, las finanzas, la banca, lucha contra la corrupción, educación, competencia, entre otras, aprendiendo de buenas prácticas de otros países.

El ministro indicó que además de aprender de las experiencias de otros países, Costa Rica también ha compartido sus avances en áreas en las que es reconocido a nivel internacional como sus políticas ambientales, el turismo sostenible, la atracción de inversiones y la apertura de mercados.

title: Trump amenaza con nuevos aranceles a la Unión Europea y Apple
content: El presidente de Estados Unidos dijo que las negociaciones comerciales con los países de la Unión Europea "no están dando frutos".
resumen: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, renovó su ofensiva comercial con amenazas de aranceles de hasta 50% a los productos de la Unión Europea (UE). Trump anunció en su red Truth Social que recomienda “imponer 50% de aranceles a la Unión Europea a partir del 1 de junio”. Trump dijo que las negociaciones comerciales con los países de la Unión Europea "no están dando frutos". Los aranceles actuales están situados en una media de 12,5% (2,5% ya vigentes antes de la investidura de Trump y un 10% adicional desde abril). El ministro delegado francés de Comercio Exterior, Laurent Saint-Martin, escribió en X: “Nos mantenemos en la misma línea: desescalada, pero estamos listos para responder”. El ministro alemán de Relaciones Exteriores, Johann Wadephul, sostuvo que esos “aranceles no ayudan a nadie y solo conducen a que el desarrollo económico de ambos mercados se resienta”. Las bolsas europeas cerraron en rojo el viernes, París cedió 1,65%, Fráncfort 1,54%, Milán 1,94% y Madrid 1,18%. Londres solo perdió 0,24%. Trump amenazó con imponer aranceles de al menos 10% a la mayoría de los productos que ingresan a Estados Unidos. Las tarifas aduaneras para China llegaron a 145% (en ciertos productos al 245%), a las que Pekín respondió con aranceles del 125%. Trump denunció el déficit comercial de Estados Unidos con Europa, que estima entre 300.000 y 350.000 millones de dólares. Según los datos del representante de la Casa Blanca para Comercio (USTR), el déficit comercial de Estados Unidos con el bloque europeo se elevó a 235.000 millones de dólares en 2024. La Comisión Europea cuestiona esas cifras y habla de 150.000 millones de euros (unos 160.000 millones de dólares), y únicamente 50.000 millones de euros si se integra el excedente comercial estadounidense en términos de servicios. El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, dijo que la tasa mínima del 10% estaba “supeditada a que los países y bloques comerciales vinieran y negociaran de buena fe”. Un portavoz de la UE dijo a la AFP que estaba prevista una llamada este viernes entre el comisario europeo de Comercio, Maros Sefcovic y el Representante de Comercio estadounidense, Jamieson Greer. Trump también amenazó a Apple con nuevos aranceles. Trump amenazó: “Hace tiempo informé a Tim Cook (presidente) de Apple que espero que sus iPhones que se vendan en Estados Unidos sean fabricados en Estados Unidos, no en India ni en otros lugares. Si no es el caso, Apple deberá pagar un arancel de al menos 25%”. El analista Dan Ives, de la consultora Wedbush Securities, dijo que mudar la producción del iPhone para Estados Unidos es “un cuento de hadas inviable”. Si se fabricaran en Estados Unidos, los iPhones costarían unos 3.500 dólares, y mudar toda la producción demoraría hasta 10 años.

title: From El Salvador to Honduras, why authoritarians gain from USAID cuts
content: USAID cuts have hurt international development work – but they’re also hampering civil society groups dedicated to preserving democracy.
resumen:
In El Salvador, Kara Wilson García's child care-focused NGO, Project RED, was promised $50,000 in USAID money, but it evaporated after the January 20 announcement of a freeze on the U.S. Agency for International Development. The crackdown under President Nayib Bukele's “state of exception” has seen homicides plummet since launching in 2022, but has simultaneously left thousands of children and adolescents forcibly abandoned by imprisoned caregivers.

USAID cuts have hurt international development work and are hampering civil society groups dedicated to preserving democracy in Central America. Civil society organizations are cutting staff and programming, and in some cases closing their doors. On May 20, El Salvador’s Legislative Assembly passed a new “foreign agents” law that imposes a 30% tax on all individuals and organizations receiving foreign funds.

Enrique Roig, former deputy assistant secretary in the U.S. State Department’s Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor, says the withdrawal of USAID funding “leaves a lot of very important democracy work much more vulnerable.”

Four of seven Central American countries sit at the bottom half of the Global State of Democracy Initiative. Nicaragua ranks 143rd, and not far behind are El Salvador (94th), Honduras (91st), and Guatemala (83rd).

In Honduras, the Forest Conservation Institute lost a project scheduled to start in March. Domestic electoral observation work by churches and universities in Honduras have been suspended due to the USAID cuts. The Washington Office on Latin America conducted an informal survey of 21 partner organizations across Central America in April, finding 70% of local organizations had to cut staff, half reported a “serious” impact on their budget, and 25% reported a “very serious” impact on their budget.

In El Salvador, 97% of USAID funding went to projects supporting issues like improving access to clean water, halting illegal migration, and training security forces. In Guatemala, Catholic Relief Services and Save The Children have been the two biggest recipients of USAID funds over the past 25 years.

Nicaraguan journalists, exiled in Costa Rica, launched a crowdfunding campaign following the U.S. cuts.

President Donald Trump announced on Feb. 3, “USAID has been run by a bunch of radical lunatics and we’re getting them out.” Secretary of State Marco Rubio announced the cancellation of 83% of USAID programs.

The White House underscored specific examples of how the funds were spent inappropriately, including "$2 million for sex change operations in Guatemala.”

Asociación Lambda, an LGBTQ+ organization in Guatemala, received a $2 million grant for a project. The project’s objective was to provide legal advice and psychological counseling. U.S. federal records show only 25% of the grant was disbursed before funding was cut.

Due to the U.S. funding cuts, the number of people Lambda provides psychological support to through this project fell from 200 to 20. Their ability to shelter members of the LGTBQ+ community dropped by 50%.

Mr. Bukele has stood behind the Trump administration’s cuts. He posted on X in February, “The majority of these [USAID] funds are funneled into opposition groups, NGOs with political agendas, and destabilizing movements.”

Only 2.5% of USAID funds since 2019 went toward programs that supported media in El Salvador, yet this industry was hit particularly hard. Some 11 media organizations were affected by the cuts and 50 journalists lost their jobs, according to the Salvadoran Journalists’ Association.

On May 20, the Legislative Assembly passed a law that now requires NGOs in El Salvador to register under a newly created Foreign Agents Registry, which prohibits them from “carrying out activities for political purposes or others that subvert public order, threaten national security, or undermine social and political stability.” Any foreign funding of civil society will be taxed 30%.

Mr. Roig says that combined with slowing global economic growth and “a lack of democratic governability ... the projections do not bode well” for Central America’s future.

title: Con mal día en el mundo, hubo rueda de estudio en la Argentina
content: Trump volvió a la carga. Amenazó con ponerle aranceles a la Unión Europea y a Apple y eso alteró las tasas norteamericanas, debilitó al dólar global e hizo bajar a Wall Street y a las Bolsas europeas.
resumen:
El mercado argentino comenzó a tratar de asimilar las facilidades entregadas por el ministro Luis Caputo para que los dólares salgan del colchón, para generar más actividad y permitir que el Banco Central sume reservas, y las primeras reacciones fueron positivas, aunque con dudas de parte de tributaristas especializados.

El dólar bajó en el mundo, hasta su menor nivel en dos años, lo que ayudó a que casi todas las cotizaciones del billete verde en Argentina apuntaran hacia abajo. El BCRA pudo recuperar reservas, con bonos y riesgo país que siguen sin reacción, pero con acciones argentinas al alza, a contramano de otro día en rojo en Wall Street y en las Bolsas europeas.

Donald Trump amenazó con aplicar aranceles del 50% a lo que llegue a Estados Unidos desde la Unión Europea y del 25% para Apple, si no hay novedades en los próximos siete días.

Citibank pronosticó que el dólar global va a seguir perdiendo valor.

Las tasas largas de EE.UU. se aplanaron: se pagó 4,2% anual a 1 año de plazo, 4,1% anual a 5 años, 4,5% anual a 10 años y 5% anual a 30 años.

El dólar cayó contra todas las monedas: perdió 1% contra el franco suizo, 1% en Japón, 0,9% contra la libra, 0,8% contra el euro, 0,4% en México y 0,3% en Brasil, Chile y China.

El dólar oficial cotizó a $1.157,43. El BCRA no intervino en el mercado, pero sumó US$ 329 millones a las reservas.

El dólar blue subió $5 hasta $1.170. El Senebi bajó $1,14 hasta $1.160,56, el MEP bajó $3,48 hasta $1.142,52 y el contado con liqui bajó $10,46 hasta $1.157,54. La brecha entre el oficial y el blue fue del 1% y la del CCL con el mayorista fue del 2%.

Tributaristas se manifestaron a favor de las medidas de Caputo, pero dudan sobre qué hará que la gente gaste el ahorro que tiene a resguardo.

El Gobierno está negociando un nuevo Repo por US$ 2.000 millones para pagar la deuda del 9 de julio próximo.

Las tasas a vencimiento de los títulos públicos argentinos se ubican entre 9% y 12% anual, con bonos internacionales que pagan entre 5% y 7% con mucho menos riesgo. El riesgo país sigue congelado en 651 puntos básicos.

El Dow bajó 0,6%, el S&P perdió 0,7% y el Nasdaq achicó 1%. La Bolsa de San Pablo subió 0,4% y la de México mejoró 0,9%.

La Bolsa de Buenos Aires subió 1,3%, con $74.403 millones operados en acciones y $60.121 millones en Cedears. Los ADR argentinos estuvieron mixtos, con subas del 1% al 3% para Loma Negra, Bioceres, Cresud, BBVA, TGS, Macro, Telecom e YPF; con bajas del 1% al 4% para Mercado Libre y Supervielle.

El petróleo subió 0,8%. Los metales básicos tuvieron un mejor clima con precios hacia arriba. Los granos sufrieron. El Bitcoin bajó 2,4%, con descensos de hasta el 4% en el resto de ese panel.

title: Trump Turns Back to His Trade War, Threatening Europe and Apple
content: The president threatened both Apple and the European Union with higher tariffs on Friday, saying trade talks with the Europeans had stalled.
resumen:
President Trump threatened to revive his global trade wars on Friday.

Mr. Trump said he would apply a steep tax to European exports starting in just over a week and warning Apple and other phone manufacturers that their products made outside the United States would face a 25 percent tariff, most likely beginning next month.

The president wrote on Truth Social on Friday morning that discussions with the European Union “are going nowhere” and that he was recommending a 50 percent tariff on European imports as of June 1.

Mr. Trump wrote, “The European Union, which was formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the United States on TRADE, has been very difficult to deal with.”

He claimed the bloc’s trade barriers, taxes, corporate penalties and other policies had contributed to a trade imbalance with the United States that was “totally unacceptable.”

In an earlier social media post, the president also targeted Tim Cook, the chief executive of Apple.

The president wrote that iPhones sold in the United States should be “manufactured and built in the United States, not India, or anyplace else.”

On Friday afternoon, Mr. Trump told reporters in the Oval Office that the 25 percent tariff on iPhones might be limited not just to Apple, but also to Samsung or any other smartphone company that makes its product outside the United States.

He said the tariffs would start “I guess the end of June.”

The president also denied that he was looking for a deal with Europe.

U.S. markets opened sharply lower, with the S&P 500 index falling more than 1 percent as trading began, before ending the day down less than 1 percent.

Apple shares dropped 3 percent.

Shares in Stellantis and Mercedes-Benz fell about 4.5 percent, and shares in Volkswagen and Porsche were down more than 3 percent.

Estimates by the Kiel Institute for the World Economy showed that the tariffs would lead to a 20 percent drop in exports from the European Union to the United States in the short term, as well as a more than 6 percent increase in prices in the United States.

Austan Goolsbee, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, warned on CNBC on Friday that the proposed import taxes raised the risk of higher prices and lower growth.

The Trump administration has been holding trade talks with over a dozen governments, including the European Union, to try to reach some kind of trade agreement before many tariffs are set to snap back into effect in early July.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said that trade offers from Europe had “not been of the same quality” that the United States had received from other countries.

The European Union’s trade commissioner, Maros Sefcovic, held a call with Jamieson Greer, the U.S. trade representative, on Friday.

Mr. Sefcovic said in a post after the meeting that “the EU’s fully engaged, committed to securing a deal that works for both,” but added that “EU-US trade is unmatched & must be guided by mutual respect, not threats. We stand ready to defend our interests.”

Officials from the 27-nation European Union have been negotiating for weeks with their American counterparts, hoping to reduce a 10 percent tariff that Mr. Trump has applied to countries globally and to reduce or avert the sector-specific tariffs he has imposed or proposed on products like cars and pharmaceuticals.

To placate Mr. Trump, the European Union has offered to reduce tariffs on industrial goods to zero, if America does the same, and increase purchases of U.S. energy.

Mr. Bessent claimed on Fox News on Friday that the countries in the European Union “don’t even know what the E.U. is negotiating on their behalf.”

Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary, described the European Union as one of the governments that have been challenging to negotiate with.

Mr. Lutnick said, “There are some countries that are impossible, like the European Union.”

Mr. Lutnick praised Mr. Trump’s negotiating strategy.

Xi Jinping, the president of China, held a telephone call with Friedrich Merz, the chancellor of Germany.

Mr. Xi offered China as a reliable economic partner to Germany and the European Union.

Within four days in early April, after Mr. Trump announced tariffs of up to 145 percent on products made in China, Apple lost $770 billion in market value.

Apple has promised to spend more than $500 billion in the United States over the next four years.

Apple has said it will buy 19 billion artificial intelligence chips made in the United States and begin manufacturing A.I. servers in Houston.

Mr. Trump said on Friday that Apple had been building plants in India, and that he had told Mr. Cook that the company should expect to face tariffs selling into the United States.

By the end of this year, an estimated 25 percent or more of iPhones will be made in India.
