title: Brazils Balancing Act Between US & China
content: Brazil’s dual-track diplomacy — favouring political ties with Beijing and commercial links with the US — may be its only viable path. As Marcos Troyjo, a former head of the New Development Bank, put ...
resumen:
As the global tussle between China and the United States intensifies, Brazil has significant leverage and much to lose.

President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva was the guest of honour at a major China–Latin America summit in Beijing, where he signed cooperation agreements and praised China. The two sides unveiled R$27bn ($4.8bn) in planned investments, part of more than 20 bilateral deals.

While Lula was in Beijing, Brazil’s state governors and corporate elite were in New York for "Brazil Week," including the leadership of JBS, the world’s largest meat producer.

Brazil is making it clear it will not choose sides in the world’s defining geopolitical contest, playing both ends against the middle.

Xi Jinping offered a glowing account of China’s growing relationship with Latin America, with trade exceeding $500bn annually. He denounced tariff wars as “bullying”.

Lula’s government is keen to boost trade, attract investment and assert Brazil’s leadership in the region. However, Brazil did not join China’s Belt and Road Initiative, and the visit produced no signature infrastructure projects. Marcos Caramuru described the outcome as “a consolidation of political dialogue” more than a leap in economic ties.

Brazil’s business leaders were reassuring investors in the US that they remain committed to the longstanding transcontinental alliance. Ricardo Alban, head of the industry confederation, stated the importance of partnership with the US.

Dario Durigan, Brazil’s deputy finance minister, emphasized that Brazil was not picking sides.

JBS opted to skip Beijing entirely, a decision likely influenced by its upcoming US stock market listing.

Brazil is one of the few countries to run a large trade surplus with China. It supplies nearly 60 per cent of the world’s soyabeans, with China the biggest buyer. Its dominance in meat exports gives it additional heft.

Brazil’s dual-track diplomacy — favouring political ties with Beijing and commercial links with the US — may be its only viable path. Marcos Troyjo stated that Brazil is more culturally aligned with the US, but for long-term investment, the Middle East, China and Singapore may offer more upside.

Lula’s government is engaging accordingly, aware of how the two superpowers operate.

Lula closed his speech in Beijing by urging Latin American unity. Brazil is trying to forge a third way that elevates its own regional influence.

Brazil remains on good terms with both Washington and Beijing. It has secured a pipeline of investment from China, while keeping financial and strategic ties with the US intact.

A hardening of the US-China standoff could make neutrality untenable. Brazil’s economic success — and its diplomatic space — depend on continued access to both markets.

With the US escalating tariffs on Chinese goods to 145 per cent, and China responding with retaliatory measures, Brazil’s hedging becomes more critical.

title: Persiste la grave crisis pecuaria en el país; ganaderos cuidan que el gusano barrenador no llegue al norte
content: A fin de combatir la plaga de gusano barrenador del ganado (GBG), el Servicio Nacional de Sanidad, Inocuidad y Calidad Agroalimentaria (Senasica) transfirió 120 millones de pesos a la Comisión ...
resumen:
La grave crisis pecuaria persiste en el país. Ganaderos coahuilenses se coordinan con autoridades federales para frenar el avance del gusano barrenador, plaga que ya ha superado la línea de contención en el sur del país.

El Servicio Nacional de Sanidad, Inocuidad y Calidad Agroalimentaria (Senasica) transfirió 120 millones de pesos a la Comisión México-Estados Unidos para la Prevención de la Fiebre Aftosa y otras Enfermedades Exóticas de los Animales (CPA) para combatir la plaga de gusano barrenador del ganado (GBG).

El presidente de la Unión Ganadera Regional de Coahuila (UGRC), Abel Ayala Flores, dijo que, si bien dicha cantidad no será suficiente para abatir la plaga, servirá para suplir fuertes erogaciones encaminadas a tal propósito.

El 1 de junio de 2023 reapareció la plaga de gusano barrenador en Panamá, la cual viajó 3 mil 700 kilómetros hasta la frontera de Guatemala y México.

El brote de gusano barrenador es una larva de mosca que deposita sus huevos en heridas abiertas de animales, representando un grave riesgo para la salud animal y la economía ganadera de México.

El gusano se había logrado erradicar en 1991.

Actualmente, solo se dispone de 100 millones de moscas estériles, suficientes apenas para cubrir el Istmo de Tehuantepec.

Desde el 30 de noviembre de 2024, la Senasica y el Servicio de Inspección Sanitaria de Animales y Plantas (APHIS, por sus siglas en inglés) han dispersado más de 885 millones de moscas estériles del GBG en el sur-sureste de México.

El secretario de Agricultura, Julio Berdegué, declaró que “México no tenía responsabilidad de controlar esa plaga cuando aún se encontraba al sur de Panamá”.

Desde noviembre de 2024 se vienen dispersando las moscas estériles disponibles, pero, a raíz del rebrote, se pactó con el gobierno estadounidense suspender por dos semanas adicionales la introducción de bovinos a ese país.

El Consejo Nacional Agropecuario calculó que el cierre de la frontera al paso de bovinos, equinos y bisontes procedentes de México significa pérdidas diarias por el orden de los 11.4 millones de dólares.

El director del Consejo Nacional Agropecuario, Luis Fernando Haro, respaldó la medida de cerrar la frontera sur de México al paso de ganado, y limitar el flujo de ganado del sur al resto del país, con objeto de prevenir lo que denominó “huachicol de ganado”.

Héctor de Hoyos, presidente de la Asociación de Engordadores de Ganado Bovino del Noreste, se pronunció en contra del cierre total de la frontera sur al ganado.

Uniones y asociaciones de ganaderos estimaron que, hasta el 1 de mayo, suman 1 mil 319 casos de gusano barrenador.

La plaga se está extendiendo a otros estados, como Oaxaca, con un caso, y otro más en Veracruz.

Álvaro Iván Bustillos Fuentes, presidente del consejo directivo de la Unión Ganadera Regional de Chihuahua, se refirió a la restricción de las exportaciones como “una historia de terror”.

La inversión anunciada el miércoles por la Senasica responde a lo previsto en el Plan Anual de Trabajo 2025 del organismo.

Dicho monto se invertirá en el reforzamiento del programa de vigilancia para la detección temprana de enfermedades y plagas exóticas y emergentes de los animales.

El acuerdo firmado por la Senasica y la referida comisión mexicoestadounidense señala que “actualmente es imperante continuar con el fortalecimiento de la infraestructura diagnóstica de los laboratorios”.

En 2024 la CPA detectó tres casos de gusano barrenador del ganado, 17 de influenza A H5N1 de alta patogenicidad y 22 de influenza A H7N3.

También se encontró un caso de influenza AH5N2 de alta patogenicidad, un caso de arteritis viral equina, un caso de durina, 10 casos de Salmonella gallinarum y 20 casos de enfermedad hemorrágica viral de los conejos.

La Senasica informó que desde junio de 2024 se han invertido alrededor de 167 millones de pesos a la erradicación del gusano barrenador desde la frontera sur del territorio mexicano.

Se han dispersado más de 885 millones de moscas estériles en el sur-sureste del territorio mexicano.

La dependencia anunció la creación de un centro fijo en el aeropuerto de Tuxtla Gutiérrez, cuya capacidad de liberación será, a partir de noviembre próximo, de 120 millones de moscas estériles por semana.

El presidente de la Unión Ganadera Regional de Coahuila (UGRC), Abel Ayala Flores, explicó que uno de los motivos por los cuales el gobierno estadounidense restringió el paso de ganado mexicano consiste precisamente en estrechar la colaboración con su contraparte mexicana para evitar que la plaga avance al norte.

Siete estados del país ya han sido afectados.
tags: ['crisis pecuaria', 'sanidad animal', 'producción agropecuaria', 'plagas agrícolas', 'medidas de control']

title: Impuesto a las remesas también perjudicarían las reservas internacionales, adelanta Hugo Noé Pino
content: El vicepresidente del Congreso Nacional, Hugo Noé Pino, señaló que la determinación del gobierno de Estados Unidos de imponer impuesto a las remesas perjudicaría también a las reservas internacionales ...
resumen:
El vicepresidente del Congreso Nacional, Hugo Noé Pino, apuntó que la determinación del gobierno de Estados Unidos de imponer impuesto a las remesas perjudicaría también a las reservas internacionales de Honduras.

Noé Pino declaró que el impacto de estos gravámenes ya ha sido cuantificado por varios sectores que si se impone un impuesto del 5 % a las remesas, el país dejaría de percibir unos 500 millones de dólares al año.

La Cámara de Representantes de EEUU aprobó un proyecto de recortes fiscales y gastos impulsados por el presidente, Donald Trump que incluye imponer impuestos a las remesas.

La iniciativa pasará al Senado para su discusión.

El diputado oficialista deseó que este proyecto no se concretice en el Senado de EEUU.

Noé Pino indicó que Honduras respetará la decisión soberana de EEUU, pero que se debe de hablar con los senadores para transmitirles el impacto que implicaría este proyecto.

Exhortó a las organizaciones hondureñas en EEUU como los que apoyan a los países pobres que sean buenos aliados.

Si se agrega a este impuesto el 10 % de las tarifas a los aranceles, parecería que Estados Unidos les está dando la espalda a los países que más necesitan recursos y sería una contrariedad a una política que trata de frenar la migración.

title: Especialista ven presión para América Latina en la administración de Trump
content: Los académicos de la Universidad de Guadalajara, aseguran que habrá presiones y chantajes para concretar la agenda que le conviene al presidente de Estados Unidos ...
resumen: Los países de América Latina y El Caribe vivirán muchas presiones en la administración del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, advierten especialistas de la Universidad de Guadalajara. Los académicos aseguran que habrá presiones y chantajes para concretar la agenda que le conviene al presidente de Estados Unidos. América Latina y el Caribe frente a la geopolítica dominante de Trump 2.0, es el título del dossier en el que participaron 31 especialistas del Centro María Sibylla de Estudios Latinoamericanos Avanzados en Humanidades y Ciencias Sociales (CALAS) de la Universidad de Guadalajara (UdeG), publicación que saldrá a la luz el próximo martes y donde analizan las políticas del presidente de la Unión Americana. El codirector del CALAS, doctor Jaime Preciado Coronado, explicó que la publicación se divide en tres secciones. La primera está enfocada en las megatendencias a escala global. La segunda sección del documento, reúne análisis sobre la región de Latinoamérica y Caribe. La tercera parte propone un bosquejo de los impactos y respuestas por países en América Latina y El Caribe. Reúne 16 textos que ofrecen un análisis de los países de una región diversa, fragmentada y con gobiernos que abarcan todo el espectro político. El académico añadió, que la política de Donald Trump frente a países de América Latina abandona el multilateralismo y ahora se basa en una serie de relaciones bilaterales, con presiones y chantajes para seguir la agenda que le conviene a ese gobierno. El Gerente General del CALAS, doctor Jochen Kemner, comentó que la publicación comparte 31 trabajos, de 38 autores, sobre la perspectiva de América Latina y El Caribe en torno a las políticas de Trump. El dossier podrá ser consultado de forma gratuita en la página: http://calas.lat/es.
tags: ['política migratoria', 'relaciones internacionales', 'presión política', 'gobierno de Estados Unidos', 'influencia política']

title: Preocupa en República Dominicana la propuesta de aranceles a las remesas desde Estados Unidos
content: Estados Unidos es la principal fuente de remesas del mundo La propuesta de un impuesto del 5 % a las remesas enviadas desde Estados Unidos, que debate ahora la Cámara de Representantes, angustia a ...
resumen:
La propuesta de un impuesto del 5 % a las remesas enviadas desde Estados Unidos, que debate ahora la Cámara de Representantes, angustia a migrantes cuyas familias dependen de este dinero, con más de 40 millones personas que resultarían afectadas en el país.

Para la República Dominicana, el gravamen podría resultar complicado para los más de un millón de quisqueyanos que envían dinero a sus familiares.

El año pasado, los dominicanos enviaron 11 mil millones de dólares a sus familiares, equivalentes a un 11 % del Producto Interno Bruto.

Los aranceles propuestos por el Gobierno de Donald Trump se agregarían al costo promedio de envío de remesas que actualmente oscila entre 5.50 y 6.69 dólares por cada 100 dólares.

La República Dominicana ocupa el tercer lugar entre los países latinoamericanos que reciben más remesas desde Estados Unidos, solo detrás de México y Guatemala.

El incremento anunciado impactaría tanto a los que envían las remesas como a las familias que las reciben.

La tasa afectaría a más de 40 millones de personas, tanto indocumentadas como residentes con "green card", y otros visados de no inmigrantes, según denunció el Caucus Hispano del Congreso (CHC).

La iniciativa, parte del polémico plan presupuestario y fiscal que impulsa el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, y que la Cámara Baja debate esta semana, aplicaría un gravamen del 5 % a las remesas transferidas desde EE. UU. al exterior.

Estados Unidos es la principal fuente de remesas del mundo, al concentrar una cuarta parte del envío total, con un estimado de más de 200,000 millones de dólares.

title: CK Hutchison defiende venta de puertos de Balboa y Cristóbal en Panamá, pese a críticas de China
content: El presidente de CK Hutchison, Victor Li, señaló este jueves 22 de mayo, que la empresa debe estar preparada para afrontar “crecientes tensiones geopolíticas” y defendió la legalidad de la operación d ...
resumen:
El presidente de CK Hutchison, Victor Li, defendió la legalidad de la operación del grupo para vender los puertos de Balboa y Cristóbal, en Panamá, a un consorcio encabezado por BlackRock.

En la asamblea general anual del conglomerado, Li aseguró que el acuerdo “cumple con las normativas vigentes”.

Li subrayó que las políticas arancelarias y la geopolítica están generando un entorno incierto.

El ejecutivo agregó que es necesario tener “un respaldo financiero robusto” para enfrentar “cualquier eventualidad”.

La alta dirección de CK Hutchison, propiedad del magnate Li Ka-shing, expuso detalles sobre la propuesta para vender los dos puertos, excluyendo los activos en Hong Kong y China, durante su primer evento público desde que se anunció la operación el pasado 4 de marzo.

El co-director Dominic Lai afirmó que “la transacción requiere un análisis exhaustivo” y que la compañía cooperará plenamente con las autoridades regulatorias.

Lai destacó el papel central de la subsidiaria de la empresa de transporte europea MSC como principal inversor desde el inicio del proceso.

El conglomerado hongkonés anunció en marzo que alcanzó un principio de acuerdo con BlackRock para adquirir el 90 % de sus participaciones en esos puertos.

Ese principio de acuerdo contemplaba la adquisición del 80 % de la participación de CK Hutchison “en empresas subsidiarias y asociadas que poseen, operan y desarrollan un total de 43 puertos, con 199 atracaderos, en 23 países”.

La Administración Estatal para la Regulación del Mercado de China advirtió de que las partes involucradas en la transacción deben cumplir estrictamente con la investigación antimonopolio en curso.

La compañía hongkonesa enfatizó que avanzar con la operación sería inviable si se presentan circunstancias ilegales o no conformes.

En la reunión, que congregó a unos 100 accionistas, se discutió la propuesta de venta de una participación mayoritaria en las operaciones al consorcio liderado por BlackRock y MSC.

title: Stocks drift to a mixed close as worries about the U.S. government’s soaring debt continue to weigh
content: Stocks drifted to a mixed close on Wall Street in what has been a rocky week because of worries coming out of the bond market about the U.S. government’s mounting debt.
resumen:
Stocks drifted to a mixed close on Wall Street Thursday due to worries about the U.S. government’s mounting debt.

The S&P 500 slipped 2.60 points, or less than 0.1%, to close at 5,842.01. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.35 points, or less than 0.1%, to 41,859.09. The Nasdaq composite rose 53.09 points, or 0.3% to 18,925.73.

Google’s parent Alphabet jumped 1.4% and Nvidia rose 0.8%.

The yield on the 10-year Treasury climbed as high as 4.63% before the U.S. stock market opened for trading, before receding to 4.54%. It stood at 4.58% late Wednesday and was as low as 4.01% early last month. The two-year yield slipped to 3.99% from 4.02% late Wednesday.

Sunrun dropped 37.1%, Enphase Energy fell 19.6% and First Solar slid 4.3%. UnitedHealth Group fell 2.1% and Humana lost 7.6%.

The number of Americans filing unemployment claims last week fell slightly.

France’s CAC 40 dropped 0.6%, Hong Kong’s Hang Seng fell 1.2% and South Korea’s Kospi slid 1.2%.

title: How much will Trump's tax bill save you? Gains could vary by income.
content: The GOP tax bill could boost the highest-earning Americans' incomes while hurting low earners, according to findings from nonpartisan research groups.
resumen: President Donald Trump says his tax bill, which won approval from a key congressional committee on May 18, would lower taxes for all Americans. It’s “increasing take-home pay for the typical family by thousands of dollars per year,” Trump said on May 1. Analyses from nonpartisan organizations suggest top earners stand to gain the most from these tax cuts, with some of the lowest earners losing income when accounting for spending cuts to programs like Medicaid. Martha Gimbel, executive director and co-founder of the Yale Budget Lab, said, "This is a bill where the positive impacts are really tilted toward rich Americans. It doesn’t really matter if people at the bottom are getting relatively small tax cuts if they're losing their health care, they're losing their SNAP benefits and they're having to pay more money in tariffs." The GOP tax plan would make the 2017 tax cuts from Trump’s first term permanent. It would increase the child tax credit to $2,500 through 2028 and $2,000 in subsequent years, and introduce other tax cuts including no taxes on tips or overtime wages. To help pay for the cuts, the government would make changes to reduce spending on the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, formerly known as food stamps, and Medicaid, a program that provides health insurance to more than 71 million low-income Americans. Analysts say the bill should add $3 trillion to $5 trillion to the country’s $36.2 trillion debt over the next decade. Moody's Ratings downgraded the country’s credit rating on May 16. The benefits of the tax bill will vary based on income, according to a new analysis from the Penn Wharton Budget Model, a nonpartisan research initiative. The top 0.1% of earners stand to gain nearly $390,000 on average in after-tax income in 2026, while Americans making between about $17,000 and $51,000 would lose about $700. Those with an income of less than $17,000 would lose more than $1,000 on average. The findings accounted for reduced spending on programs like Medicaid and SNAP. Another analysis from the Yale Budget Lab in March found similar results. The lowest earners would see a 5% reduction in after-tax-and-transfer income when spending cuts are taken into account, while the top earners would see a roughly 3% increase. Increased prices from tariffs would only make matters worse for low-income households, Gimbel said. Previous reports from the Budget Lab found the lowest-earning households will feel the biggest blow from tariffs, especially in the short term, because they spend a larger share of their income on goods that will go up in price. Gimbel said, “It is frankly a brutal one-two punch for lower- and middle-income families.” The White House pointed to a May report from the Council of Economic Advisers that says tax cuts would strengthen the economy and drive up incomes and wages. The CEA says "all Americans will benefit," with a typical family with two kids expected to see take-home pay increase $7,800 to $13,300 through increased wages and reduced taxes. The average overtime worker would receive a tax cut of between $1,400 and $1,750 per year, according to the study. White House Principal Deputy Communications Director Alex Pfeiffer told USA TODAY in a May 20 statement, "Let’s be clear, not passing the One Big Beautiful bill means letting the 2017 Trump Tax Cuts expire and most Americans will see their taxes increase. It will boost take home pay for the typical family with 2 kids by roughly $13,000 a year and boost overtime workers’ take-home pay by $1,750 a year.” Pfeiffer also cited findings from a May 13 report from the Joint Committee on Taxation that found Americans making between $30,000 and $80,000 a year would pay roughly 15% less in taxes in 2027. Another analysis from the Penn Wharton Budget Model that takes Medicaid and SNAP spending cuts into account found the tax bill as written on May 19 would increase federal debt by 7.2% and the average wage would fall “slightly” over the next decade, while GDP would be 0.5% higher than under current law. Overall, the top 10% of the income distribution – which currently pays roughly 70% of federal taxes – would receive about 65% of the total value of the tax bill. Kent Smetters, faculty director of the Penn Wharton Budget Model, said, “Overall, there will be economic growth. It won’t be enough to help low-income households because it’s coming from them, in the sense that they have to save more, consume less, work more.”

title: What is the new US-backed Gaza aid plan and why doesn't the UN like it?
content: A U.S.-backed organization aims to start work in the Gaza Strip by the end of May, overseeing a new model of aid distribution in the Palestinian enclave, but the United Nations says the plan is not ...
resumen:
A U.S.-backed organization, the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF), aims to start work in the Gaza Strip by the end of May, overseeing a new model of aid distribution. The United Nations says the plan is not impartial or neutral, and it will not be involved.

The GHF was established in February in Switzerland, according to the Geneva commercial registry.

The foundation intends to work with private U.S. security and logistics firms - UG Solutions and Safe Reach Solutions. The GHF has already received more than $100 million in commitments.

Senior U.S. officials were working with Israel to enable the GHF to start work. Israel said it will facilitate the GHF's work without being involved in aid deliveries.

The GHF said initially there will be four secure distribution sites - three in the south and one in central Gaza - and that "within the next month, additional sites will be opened, including in northern Gaza."

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Thursday that construction of the first distribution zones would be complete in the coming days and that Israel intends "to have large safe zones in the south of Gaza."

The GHF said it would "never participate in or support any form of forced relocation of civilians" and that there was no limit on the number of sites it could open, or where.

The GHF will use security contractors to transport aid from border crossings to the secure distribution sites. Once the aid is at the sites, it will be distributed directly to the people of Gaza by civilian humanitarian teams.

Israel's U.N. Ambassador Danny Danon has said a few aid groups have agreed to work with the GHF. The names of those groups are not yet known.

The foundation said it is finalizing mechanisms to get aid to those who cannot access the distribution sites.

GHF also said it would not share any personally identifiable information of aid recipients with Israel and that the Israeli military "will not have a presence within the immediate vicinity of the distribution sites."

The United Nations says the U.S.-backed distribution plan does not meet its long-held principles of impartiality, neutrality and independence.

U.N. aid chief Tom Fletcher has said time should not be wasted on the alternative proposal.

Israel stopped all aid deliveries to Gaza on March 2 after accusing Hamas of stealing aid, which the Palestinian militants deny, and demanding the release of all remaining hostages taken during an October 2023 attack on Israel that killed 1,200 people. That assault triggered the war, which Gaza authorities say has killed 53,000 people in the enclave.

In early April, Israel proposed what it described as "a structured monitoring and aid entry mechanism" for Gaza. It was swiftly rejected by U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres.

A global hunger monitor last week warned that half a million people face starvation - about a quarter of the population in the enclave - and U.S. President Donald Trump acknowledged that "a lot of people are starving in Gaza."

Amid the stalemate over Israel's plan, Washington backed the newly-created GHF to oversee aid distribution.

The GHF announced last week that it aims to start work in Gaza by the end of May. In the meantime, Israel has allowed limited aid deliveries to resume this week under the existing distribution model.

Throughout the conflict, the United Nations has described its humanitarian operation in Gaza as opportunistic - facing problems with Israel's military operation, access restrictions by Israel into and throughout Gaza, and looting by armed gangs.

The U.N. has said its aid distribution system works, and that was particularly proven during a two-month ceasefire, which was abandoned by Israel in mid-March. Israel first inspects and approves aid. It is then dropped off on the Gaza side of the border, where it was picked up by the U.N. and distributed.

U.N. spokesperson Stephane Dujarric said on Monday: "We do not need to reinvent yet another wheel. We don't need a newly minted humanitarian partner to tell us how to do our work in Gaza."

Fletcher on Monday listed what the U.N. needs from Israel to scale up aid: at least two open crossings into Gaza - one in the north and one in the south; simplified, expedited procedures; no quotas; no access impediments in Gaza and no attacks when aid is being delivered; and being allowed to meet a range of needs, including food, water, hygiene, shelter, health, fuel and gas.

title: El ruido de Trump como mercancía
content: Frente al aparente caos creado por Trump, la tarea es comprender el papel del ruido como medio de conocimiento para pronosticar futuros ...
resumen:
El ruido es un sonido no deseado que sirve para ocultar otros sonidos. El texto analiza las relaciones del ruido con el dinero, el poder y la política, enfocándose en el ruido provocado por Donald Trump.

Se mencionan varios "ruidos" asociados a Trump:

*   Intimidación por medio de aranceles.
*   Amenazas de apropiarse de Groenlandia y recuperar el canal de Panamá.
*   Exigencias a universidades privadas para reducir ideas progresistas y antisemitas.
*   Dejar sin efecto políticas sobre diversidad, equidad e inclusión.
*   Modificar reglas de admisión de estudiantes y expulsar a quienes protesten.
*   El ruido en torno a la violencia del tráfico de narcóticos y su relación con México.
*   El cierre a las inversiones que llegaban a México, según el embajador Ken Salazar el 13 de noviembre de 2024.
*   La decisión del presidente López Obrador de solicitar el retiro de la DEA.
*   Publicaciones en medios estadounidenses (ProPublica y New York Times) con campañas en redes sociales y hashtags como #AMLO narcopresidente y Claudia narcopresidenta.

Donald John Trump, nacido el 14 de junio de 1946 en Queens, Nueva York, es un empresario y político conservador estadounidense. Fue el 45º presidente de los Estados Unidos (20 de enero de 2017-20 de enero de 2021) y actualmente es el 47º presidente de los Estados Unidos (desde el 20 de enero de 2025). Obtuvo un título en economía en la Wharton School de la Universidad de Pensilvania en 1968. En febrero de 2018, Forbes lo ubicó en el puesto 766 de las personas más ricas del mundo, con un valor neto de 3600 millones de dólares.

Trump ganó las elecciones generales del 8 de noviembre de 2016 contra Hillary Clinton, a pesar de perder el voto popular por aproximadamente tres millones de votos, debido a su victoria en el Colegio Electoral. Asumió la presidencia el 20 de enero de 2017 a los 70 años. Es la primera persona en ejercer la presidencia en la historia de Estados Unidos siendo condenado penalmente por el sistema judicial, y el primero sin servicio militar ni cargo político ejercido anteriormente.

Acciones de Trump:

*   Redujo asilos y admisiones de refugiados.
*   Intentó eliminar la ciudadanía estadounidense automática para hijos de extranjeros nacidos en suelo estadounidense.
*   Ampliación del muro fronterizo entre México y Estados Unidos.
*   Prohibición de viajar a ciudadanos de países de mayoría musulmana.
*   Derogó la sentencia Roe vs. Wade de 1973.
*   Retiró a Estados Unidos del Acuerdo Transpacífico de Cooperación Económica y el Acuerdo de París sobre cambio climático.
*   Reconoció a Jerusalén como la capital de Israel.
*   Retiró a Estados Unidos del Acuerdo sobre el programa nuclear de Irán.
*   Impuso aranceles de importación a diversos productos de China, Canadá, México, la Unión Europea.

El texto sugiere que el ruido de Trump es un disfraz del poder monologante y un medio de percibir el mundo, donde las reglas de la conversación son inexistentes. Se plantea que las amenazas de represión se extenderán a diversos ámbitos. Se concluye que si el ruido de Trump es una mercancía que busca ensordecer, la sordera del público dificultará la reorganización económica del capitalismo.

title: Lamenta Felipe Calderón que Trump no ordene intervenir en países de AL
content: Madrid. El ex presidente de México Felipe Calderón Hinojosa lamentó que durante el gobierno de Donald Trump no habrá intervención en América Latina y que, si acaso, sólo se volcará en controlar el ...
resumen: El ex presidente de México Felipe Calderón Hinojosa lamentó que durante el gobierno de Donald Trump no habrá intervención en América Latina y que, si acaso, sólo se volcará en controlar el Canal de Panamá y el Golfo de México. Calderón, quien gobernó México entre 2006 y 2012, participó en el seminario internacional organizado por el ultraderechista Grupo de Libertad y Democracia, cuyo primer debate se llevó a cabo en el Ateneo de Madrid. En el encuentro volvieron a arremeter contra los gobiernos de izquierda de la región y expresaron su apoyo a los venezolanos Edmundo González, quien asistió al encuentro, y María Corina Machado. El panel de debate en el que participó Calderón se título América, Europa y los cambios de paradigma marcados por Estados Unidos. El ex presidente mexicano lamentó que con la nueva administración en Estados Unidos no habrá intervención en América Latina. Así lo afirmó: “en América Latina hay una retracción de Estados Unidos, por eso Washington se retrae de Ucrania, porque no quiere gastar dinero en la defensa de países que sus votantes no conocen. Hay preocupantes razones para decir: pierdan toda esperanza no habrá intervención americana en América Latina, salvo la que tenga que ver con una visión neomonroísta de los americanos; de América para los americanos. Por eso habrá más visión sobre el Canal de Panamá, el Golfo de México y sobre otros”. Calderón Hinojosa aseguró que estamos frente a un “cambio total de paradigma: se acabó el viejo orden de un Estados Unidos cooperante y líder del mundo. ¡It’s over!”, aseguró. El ex líder de la derecha mexicana explicó que los cambios en la política arancelaria impulsados por Donald Trump llevarán a México a la recesión: pienso que el establecimiento de aranceles se va a quedar, con algunos ajustes, pero se va a quedar con consecuencias económicas, como una bajada del crecimiento económico mundial, recesión en muchos casos y en el caso de México, claramente habrá una recesión este año y no creo que sea el único país. El vaticinio de Calderón es que Estados Unidos perderá influencia y liderazgo en el mundo y en América Latina frente a Rusia y China. En cuanto a la reforma judicial, Calderón afirmó que es básicamente la destrucción del Poder Judicial, tiene el riesgo de que éste quede capturado por intereses políticos del partido en el poder, que es claramente la estrategia, pero también por intereses tan peligrosos como el narcotráfico, y eso deja a México en un terrible estado de indefensión, reforzando los signos autoritarios, cancelando las vías democráticas poco a poco pero de manera consistente, y abriendo una puerta peligrosísima a que el Poder Judicial esté controlado al menos en parte o al menos en algunas regiones por el crimen organizado. El foro fue apoyado por los ex presidentes españoles José María Aznar y Mariano Rajoy, y por el líder actual del Partido Popular (PP), Alberto Núñez Feijóo. En su intervención, Aznar aseguró que Trump ha capitalizado el extravío extremista de los demócratas y ha rentabilizado el miedo, el malestar, la sensación de declive y el hastío de una población mayoritariamente harta de un populismo delirante. Un sufragio negativo ha vuelto a decidir la dirección de la primera potencia del planeta y éste parece ser es un signo de los tiempos. Este foro tendrá su debate principal este jueves en Oviedo, en el Teatro Campoamor, donde se prevén también protestas de repulsa a su presencia y a su discurso de odio.

title: US-China Tensions Escalate Over Huawei’s AI Chips Amid Export Controls
content: China’s Commerce Ministry warns individuals and companies enforcing US export restrictions on Huawei AI chips of legal consequences under its Anti-Foreign Sanctions Law, escalating tech and trade tens ...
resumen: The dispute over Huawei’s advanced chips highlights persistent tensions despite positive rhetoric from US and Chinese negotiators during last week’s trade talks in Geneva. China’s Commerce Ministry in Beijing issued a statement on Wednesday threatening legal action against individuals or organisations implementing US export restrictions on Huawei’s AI processors, Bloomberg reported. The ministry claimed that such actions violate China’s Anti-Foreign Sanctions Law and other regulations, warning that those involved “must bear corresponding legal responsibilities.” This follows the Trump administration’s issuance of guidelines on May 13, which alongside the revocation of Joe Biden’s Artificial Intelligence Diffusion rule, reminded companies that using Huawei’s Ascend chips “anywhere in the world” violates US export controls. Over the past week Beijing has repeatedly criticised Washington for issuing warnings against using Huawei’s AI chips, particularly the Ascend series, accusing the Trump administration of undermining a preliminary trade agreement reached in Geneva on May 10, 2025. This agreement included a 90-day tariff pause, reducing US tariffs on Chinese goods from 145% to 30% and Chinese tariffs on US goods from 125% to 10%, to facilitate broader trade negotiations. China’s Commerce Ministry called the US measures “discriminatory” and “market-distorting”, arguing they threaten the stability of the global semiconductor supply chain and undermine the Geneva consensus. The ongoing friction underscores significant challenges in bridging differences on key issues. Earlier this week China asserted that the Trump administration’s guidelines undermined the progress made in recent trade discussions. The US Commerce Department revised its guidance on Huawei’s Ascend AI chips, originally issued on May 13, 2025. The initial guidance, released on May 12, 2025, stated that “using Huawei Ascend chips anywhere in the world would violate US export controls.” The updated version removed the phrase “anywhere in the world”, signalling a shift in the scope of the restrictions. Huawei’s Ascend chips, designed for training AI models, are positioned to compete with Nvidia’s dominance in high-end chip design. These chips are a cornerstone of Chinese leader Xi Jinping’s strategy to enhance China’s domestic capabilities in developing advanced chips, as part of a broader push for AI supremacy against the United States. At a high-level political meeting last month Xi emphasised “self-reliance” in AI development, stating that China would leverage its “new whole-of-nation system” to accelerate technological independence and innovation. This approach aims to reduce reliance on foreign technology amid escalating US export controls targeting Huawei and other Chinese firms.

title: Trade conflicts erode US global leadership
content: The global economy is under mounting pressure from slow growth, inflation, geopolitical instability, and intensifying trade tensions. These factors heighten the risk of a global recession, as existing ...
resumen:
The temporary de-escalation of China-US trade tensions can temporarily soothe the global market's nerves. The tariff conflict between the world's two largest economies serves no one's interests.

While the stated objective of the US administration's policy to impose high tariffs was to decrease the United States' trade deficit with China, the underlying motivations extend beyond economics to geopolitical considerations. Washington aims to impede China's global technological expansion.

In the face of the escalating trade war with the US, China has adopted an integrated stimulus policy to further stabilize the domestic economy and minimize the impact of US tariffs. Chinese government spending in 2025 increased to more than 8 percent of GDP, compared to 6.6 percent in the previous year, in a move aimed at stimulating domestic demand and increasing productivity in key sectors. This policy reflects an integrated strategy to boost the domestic economy and reduce dependence on foreign markets, within the framework of expanding the national economy.

The global economy is under mounting pressure from slow growth, inflation, geopolitical instability, and intensifying trade tensions. These factors heighten the risk of a global recession, as existing economic measures are proving insufficient to stabilize the fragile system.

The intensification of US tariffs under the US administration has triggered significant realignments in global trade dynamics, with China actively exploiting the opportunity to deepen ties with Washington's traditional partners. China is courting the EU and Southeast Asian nations through diplomatic efforts and promises of increased trade. Several countries — particularly in Europe and Asia — see potential in trade cooperation with China, especially if it includes investments and technology transfer. Simultaneously, dissatisfaction with the unpredictability of the US administration has pushed countries such as Canada, Mexico, and EU members to seek certainty elsewhere, including through greater cooperation with China and among themselves.

The global trade system appears increasingly fragmented. Two emerging blocs illustrate this: the "open market allies", composed of relatively free-trade advocates such as the EU, Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership members, and other developed economies; and the "strategic hedgers", including India, Brazil, and South Africa, which seek to balance between US and Chinese influence with a pragmatic trade approach. These shifts mark a move away from a US-centric trade order toward a more multipolar, flexible structure, with countries diversifying alliances to secure their economic interests amid rising protectionism.

The ongoing trade dispute between the United States and China has the potential to accelerate the transition toward a multipolar global system by undermining the dominance of the traditional liberal economic order and encouraging other global powers to assert greater autonomy. This strategic diversification opens space for other players such as the EU, India, and regional coalitions such as the Association of Southeast Asian Nations to play more prominent roles in shaping trade norms, standards and alliances.

The erosion of US leadership — fueled by protectionist policies and withdrawal from multilateral agreements — has particularly enabled China to present itself as a champion of globalization, attracting nations seeking stable economic partnerships. As a result, trade fragmentation, economic nationalism, and regionalism are contributing to a more decentralized world order where power is diffused among multiple centers.

The emergence of a true multipolar system is not guaranteed and may be constrained by structural imbalances and systemic dependencies. Despite the disruption caused by the trade war, the US and China still dominate global finance, technological innovation, and military power, limiting the ability of other states to fully break free from their influence.

Many potential poles in the multipolar vision — such as the EU or India — face internal economic or political challenges that hinder their capacity to act cohesively or globally. The deep entanglement of global supply chains, particularly in critical sectors like semiconductors and rare earths, still centers around China and the US, making any decoupling partial and selective at best. Therefore, while the trade conflict does create space for alternative power centers and new trade configurations, it is more likely to lead to a fragmented or competitive multipolarity rather than a stable, balanced multipolar global system.

China remains in a strong position to strengthen its role in the global economy through several key strategies. By strengthening multilateral economic cooperation and expanding its trade partnerships in regions such as Asia, Africa and Latin America, China can continue to build and strengthen its economic network. It is also further enhancing its global competitiveness by investing heavily in future technology such as artificial intelligence and renewable energy.

The author is an associate professor of Political Science and International Relations, Suez Canal University and the Institute of Arab Research and Studies, Arab Republic of Egypt.

title: Donald Trump to attend G7 summit in Canada amid rising trade tensions
content: Trump's upcoming visit to the G7 summit in Canada is set to spotlight rising trade tensions, with tariffs, China, and global economic concerns topping the agenda.
resumen: US President Donald Trump will attend the G7 summit in Canada in June. The White House confirmed this amid escalating trade tensions between the participating nations. This will be Trump's first visit to Canada in his second presidency. Prime Minister Mark Carney is set to host President Donald Trump and other G7 leaders—including French President Emmanuel Macron and UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer—in Kananaskis, Alberta, from June 15 to 17. Import tariffs imposed by President Trump are expected to take center stage at the upcoming summit. Earlier this week, G7 finance ministers—including U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent—gathered in Canada to address growing concerns over slowing economic growth and rising inflation, both driven in part by ongoing trade disputes.

title: Singapore has never stayed neutral and does take positions on trade with US and China: Gan Kim Yong
content: Singapore has never stayed neutral and will always take a position on policies or international issues, said Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong at a conference on May 22. Among the thorniest of those ...
resumen: Singapore has never stayed neutral and will always take a position on policies or international issues, said Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong at a conference on May 22. Among the thorniest of those issues are the trade tensions between the US and China. Singapore cannot stay permanently on the sidelines. Singapore will take a stance based on what is in its best interests, for the country and citizens. DPM Gan, who is also the Trade and Industry Minister, added that Singapore values doing business with the US and with China, and both countries know its position. It is becoming "increasingly difficult and challenging" to "find a way that will be comfortable for both sides". The May 12 deal — where the US and China agreed to suspend part of their tariffs on each other's goods for 90 days — may provide a temporary reprieve. It is not going to be business as usual at the end of this tariff crisis. "It is going to be a new world," added DPM Gan, who was speaking with Young Jin Yee, co-head of UBS Global Wealth Management Asia-Pacific, at the Wealth Edition of the UBS Asian Investment Conference at Capella Singapore. Trade talks have been increasingly centred on domestic needs, and countries are becoming more protectionist. The Government formed the Singapore Economic Resilience Taskforce in April to help businesses and workers navigate the near-term challenges arising from the US tariffs and to position the country in the new economic landscape. DPM Gan chairs the task force, which comprises four other ministers and representatives from the Singapore Business Federation, the National Trades Union Congress and the Singapore National Employers Federation. The Government will focus on priorities, including investing in innovation and research and development to create new businesses, new products, new services and even new markets, as well as new business models. Singapore must also continue to invest in its people, its most critical resource. "Every industry, every business needs to continue to invest in developing our local talent, bringing in talent and building a team together." Singapore must stay nimble and be prepared to move fast, change fast and respond fast when the business environment changes. He was also part of the multi-ministry task force formed during the Covid-19 pandemic, earning him the nickname "task force man". "We are quite fond of forming teams and task forces so that we are able to tackle issues collectively," he said, noting that this approach is the most effective way to tap the range of local expertise given Singapore's small size and limited resources.

title: Trump to attend G7 Summit in Canada amid trade tensions
content: The G7 Summit will be held in Kananaskis from June 15 to 17. Tensions between the two countries have heightened following Trump’s announcement of imposing sweeping tariffs on Canada, a move that threa ...
resumen: US President Donald Trump will visit Canada in June to attend the G7 Summit. The White House announced this on Thursday, as tensions over trade loom large. This is the first time Trump will be travelling to Canada in his second presidency. The G7 Summit will be held in Kananaskis from June 15 to 17. Tensions between the two countries have heightened following Trump’s announcement of imposing sweeping tariffs on Canada. Trump’s import tariffs are expected to be a major focus during the summit. In May, the president announced a trade deal with the United Kingdom. The Group of Seven’s top finance ministers, including US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, met in Canada to discuss the worrying trends of slower growth and higher inflation triggered by the trade war. Ukrainian Finance Minister Sergii Marchenko attended the talks and urged the G7 to maintain pressure on Russia.

title: What do Trump tariffs mean for the United States-Mexico-Canada agreement?
content: Mark R. Ludwikowski and Kelsey Christensen of Clark Hill PLC discuss the Trump administration tariffs and their implications on compliance with the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement.
resumen:
In the ever-evolving landscape of North American trade, businesses find themselves navigating the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement ("USMCA") and the shifting tariff policies under the Trump administration. Understanding the nuances of the Trump tariffs and their implications on USMCA compliance is crucial for companies operating across these borders. Ensuring USMCA compliance yields increased benefits under the current tariff system.

Since January, the Trump administration has orchestrated a series of tariffs aimed at recalibrating trade imbalances and safeguarding national security. Noteworthy among these are the International Emergency Economic Powers Act ("IEEPA") fentanyl tariffs on imports from China (20%), Mexico (25%), and Canada (25%); an expansion of Section 232 tariffs on steel (25%) and aluminum (25%) imports to encompass downstream products, along with the removal of previous exemptions; reciprocal tariffs which currently sit at 10% for all countries but climbed to 125% for Chinese imports; and automotive sector-based tariffs, which have seen subsequent amendments.

The USMCA, negotiated by the first Trump administration, replaced the North American Free Trade Agreement ("NAFTA") with a focus on enhancing labor and environmental standards, promoting digital trade, and fortifying intellectual property protections. A significant overhaul was seen in the rules of origin requirements, particularly in the automotive sector, which elevated the regional value content requirements.

The specific rules of origin requirements vary across product types. The calculus for many businesses has shifted with the recent tariff hikes, making USMCA compliance more enticing compared to the relatively modest benefits of previous USMCA tariff advantages.

Amid the Trump administration's tariff escalations, USMCA offers a more pronounced benefit. The cumulative and "stacking" nature of these tariffs significantly elevates costs for importers. Businesses are increasingly motivated to capitalize on identifying and using the limited exemptions built into the new tariffs.

As of March 2025 the IEEPA-fentanyl tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada have been adjusted to exempt USMCA-qualified goods. While non-USMCA compliant imports from Canada and Mexico face a 12% reciprocal tariff, USMCA-compliant goods remain exempt.

Businesses also need to assess whether industry or product-specific tariffs apply to their imports. One such example is the 25% tariff on automobiles and automotive parts. Ensuring USMCA compliance offers North American businesses significant tariff advantages over non-USCMA compliant automotive imports; for USMCA compliance automotive imports, the 25% tariff applies only to the value of the non-U.S. content of the import rather than to the total value of the import.

Recent tariff implementations, namely the IEEPA-fentanyl and Section 232 tariffs, disallow duty drawbacks, thereby preventing importers from recouping costs even if the goods are re-exported and never used in the United States.

The USMCA permits a process known as reconciliation, allowing for post-importation corrections to the origin status of goods. This process enables importers to claim preferential treatment retroactively within a limited timeframe, contingent upon the genuine certification of compliance with USMCA origin rules.

As tariffs on non-USMCA imports rise, businesses are likely to intensify their focus on certifying their imported products and leveraging reconciliation to recuperate duties.

The tariff landscape of 2025 has ushered in profound changes demanding strategic adaptations by businesses. For many, this means investing in USMCA certification and compliance measures.

Staying informed of policy shifts, such as industry-specific Section 232 actions, is paramount for strategic foresight and cost management. Developing robust valuation and compliance programs will facilitate navigation of potential audits by U.S. Customs and Border Protection and fortify businesses against enforcement actions.

Anticipated reviews of the USMCA in 2026 and new bilateral negotiations suggest that the trade environment will remain dynamic. Proactive compliance efforts and meaningful dialogue across all levels of the supply chain will be essential for companies to adapt and thrive in this evolving landscape.

Mark R. Ludwikowski is a regular contributing columnist on international trade for Reuters Legal News and Westlaw Today.

Mark R. Ludwikowski is a member of Clark Hill PLC and the leader of its international trade practice, based in the Washington, D.C., office.

Kelsey Christensen is an associate in Clark Hill PLC’s international trade practice, based in the Washington, D.C. office.

title: Opinión FT: Brasil puede ser el ganador en el duelo entre EEUU y China
content: El líder chino r ecibió a tres presidentes latinoamericanos y a un grupo de ministros de relaciones exteriores en una cumbre regional celebrada en Beijing la semana pasada. El comercio entre China y ...
resumen:
El artículo de Financial Times, publicado el jueves 22 de mayo de 2025, a las 09:17, titulado "Opinión FT: Brasil puede ser el ganador en el duelo entre EEUU y China", escrito por Michael Stott, analiza la posición de Brasil en el contexto de las relaciones entre Estados Unidos y China.

El líder chino, Xi Jinping, recibió a tres presidentes latinoamericanos y ministros de relaciones exteriores en una cumbre regional en Beijing, donde el comercio entre China y América Latina superó los US$ 500 mil millones el año pasado, un aumento de 40 veces en 25 años. El presidente brasileño, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, fue invitado estrella y se firmaron acuerdos de cooperación sino-brasileños por valor de 27 mil millones de reales (US$ 4.800 millones).

En Nueva York, ejecutivos y políticos brasileños restaron importancia a las sugerencias de que la presidencia de Trump había cambiado la relación comercial entre EEUU y Brasil. Ricardo Alban, presidente de la confederación brasileña de la industria, destacó la historia de más de 200 años de relaciones con EEUU.

Marcos Troyjo, expresidente del Nuevo Banco de Desarrollo (NBD), mencionó que Brasil se alinea más culturalmente con EEUU, pero los empresarios brasileños ven más socios potenciales en China, Medio Oriente o Singapur para inversiones a largo plazo.

Darío Durigan, secretario ejecutivo del Ministerio de Hacienda de Brasil, afirmó que Brasil se está posicionando como un puerto seguro.

Brasil registra un gran superávit comercial con China y domina las exportaciones mundiales de soya (casi el 60%) y carne, productos en los que China es el principal importador.

Marcos Caramuru, exembajador en China, dijo que la visita de Lula consolidó el diálogo político y la amistad personal con Xi.

El artículo sugiere que Brasil, y no China, podría ser el ganador de la situación.

title: South Africa Wanted to Talk Trade. Then Trump Turned Down the Lights.
content: In a bruising Oval Office meeting, the visitors’ plan to keep President Trump from focusing on false accusations of white genocide backfired spectacularly.
resumen: For President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, the meeting in the Oval Office was meant to be a chance to hit the reset button. He got President Trump to giggle with a joke about golf. He offered him a book. He kept the compliments flowing, thanking Mr. Trump for providing South Africa with respirators during the Covid-19 pandemic. Mr. Ramaphosa’s meeting in the White House on Wednesday, South African officials stressed that they would not focus on Mr. Trump’s recent claims of white genocide. Instead they would talk about tariffs, South Africa’s valuable minerals and strengthening business ties between the two countries. Mr. Ramaphosa walked away from the meeting bruised and still carrying uncertainty over the future of his country’s crucial relationship with the United States. His effort to avoid the discussion of the so-called genocide and the recent arrival of 59 white South Africans labeled refugees by the Trump administration appeared to backfire spectacularly. South Africa finds itself with more work to do to avert steep tariffs, secure a new trade agreement and set the record straight on Mr. Trump’s continued accusations of racism against white people. Patrick Gaspard, the former United States ambassador to South Africa, said, “Today’s performance, if it does not lead to meaningful reconciliation, will only create more downward pressure on poor South Africans who struggle.” South Africa needs the United States more than ever, with unemployment and inequality soaring, economic growth tepid and violence against South Africans of all races rampant. Mr. Ramaphosa sought to get reassurances from the White House that his country could continue to rely on the United States, its second largest trading partner, as a market for South African goods and as a source of investment in the nation’s economy. Mr. Trump ordered his people to turn down the lights in the Oval Office. An aide standing next to a big-screen television popped open a laptop and pressed play. A montage of clips featuring Julius Malema, a firebrand leftist South African politician, began to play. In the clips, Mr. Malema leads apartheid-era chants calling for South Africans to kill Afrikaners. For the next 40 minutes, as the world watched live, Mr. Ramaphosa could do little to stop Mr. Trump from framing the meeting on his terms. Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, deposited a stack of news clips on a table next to Mr. Trump with headlines about white South Africans. Mr. Trump even got Retief Goosen — one of the championship golfers Mr. Ramaphosa had brought to the meeting to help dispel myths about white persecution — to reveal that his family used an electric fence for protection and that his mother had been the victim of an attack. Mr. Trump equated the circumstances — falsely — that white South Africans currently face to the atrocities of apartheid. Mr. Trump said, “what’s happening now is never reported.” Mr. Ramaphosa’s efforts to address the footage were drowned out by Mr. Trump, who went so far as to wave off the South African leader when he attempted to talk over the video. Mr. Trump declined to say he knew for certain that there was genocide against white people happening in South Africa, and Mr. Ramaphosa counted that as a win. Mr. Ramaphosa said, “I do believe that there’s doubt and disbelief in his head about all of this.” The two sides held a working lunch following the Oval Office gathering, and Mr. Ramaphosa briefed journalists in a hotel ballroom afterward. He was greeted by halting applause from members of his delegation. Mr. Ramaphosa said, “All in all, I do believe that our visit here has been a great success,” arguing that once the cameras were off, the conversation was no longer contentious. South Africa presented a framework for a trade deal, the president said, and the two sides agreed to hold further discussions to iron out the specifics of an agreement. He said that Mr. Trump indicated that he would attend the Group of 20 summit in Johannesburg in November. Senator Chris Van Hollen, a Democrat from Maryland, said that if South Africa, the continent’s largest economy, continued to feel isolated by the United States, it could damage American interests as well. He said, “I see this as Donald Trump retreating from the Global South and ceding leadership to China and other adversaries.” Mr. Ramaphosa did manage to avoid one contentious discussion during the meeting: Mr. Trump’s delegation did not even bring up the genocide case that South Africa filed against Israel for the war in Gaza.

title: “Seguimos negociando”: Sheinbaum tras llamada con Donald Trump sobre aranceles
content: Aunque México se libró de los llamados aranceles recíprocos que Trump anunció contra decenas de países, los sectores automotor y siderúrgico sí enfrentan gravámenes.
resumen:
La presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum dijo el jueves 22 de mayo que su gobierno sigue negociando con Estados Unidos para alcanzar un acuerdo comercial, tras sostener una llamada telefónica con Donald Trump.
Sheinbaum dijo que siguen hablando sobre los temas comerciales, siguen negociando, con buena relación y buena comunicación, sin dar más detalles de la llamada.
El secretario de Economía, Marcelo Ebrard, viajará el viernes 23 de mayo a Washington para una reunión.
La Inversión Extranjera Directa (IED) en México alcanzó los 21.400 millones de dólares en el primer trimestre del año.
Los sectores automotor y siderúrgico sí enfrentan gravámenes.
Los automóviles fabricados en México para exportación a Estados Unidos podrán pagar un arancel del 15% en vez del 25%, según una nueva disposición de Washington.
Desde el pasado 3 de abril, los vehículos importados a Estados Unidos están gravados con un 25%, excepto aquellas piezas procedentes de Canadá y México cubiertas por el tratado de libre comercio de América del Norte (T-MEC).

Ma mantuvo el martes en Pekín una reunión con el nuevo embajador estadounidense en China, David Perdue, a quien pidió que su país “trabaje con China para promover conjuntamente el desarrollo estable, saludable y sostenible” de las relaciones bilaterales. title: Negocios colombianos que están en vilo por aranceles de Donald Trump: hay crudo panorama
content: Negocios de logística en Colombia, en vilo por aranceles de Donald Trump | Dicen cómo viene situación en nuestro país.
resumen: La reciente decisión del gobierno de Estados Unidos de aumentar en un 10 % los aranceles a productos importados ha generado preocupación en Colombia, especialmente en el sector logístico, al ser EE. UU. uno de los principales destinos de exportaciones nacionales. Esta medida podría reducir hasta en un 30 % las exportaciones colombianas, generando impactos negativos en los costos operativos, rutas comerciales y tiempos de entrega. Según la Encuesta Nacional de Logística, los costos logísticos ya representan el 17,9 % de la operación empresarial. Expertos como Juan Ángel, de Drivin, señalan que el aumento arancelario incrementará los precios de insumos importados y exigirá una replanificación logística. Factores como la apreciación del dólar y los cambios aduaneros podrían provocar retrasos, afectando especialmente a productos perecederos. La tecnología aparece como una herramienta clave. El reciente aumento del 10 % en los aranceles por parte del gobierno de Estados Unidos a los productos importados impacta significativamente a la economía colombiana, afectando especialmente a los negocios que dependen del comercio exterior y de insumos importados. Estados Unidos es uno de los principales socios comerciales de Colombia. Este tipo de medidas encarece el precio final de los productos colombianos en el mercado estadounidense, reduciendo su competitividad, e incrementa los costos de operación interna en Colombia. Las empresas deben enfrentar un aumento en el valor de las materias primas y de los insumos que provienen del extranjero, lo cual se traduce en mayores costos de producción y distribución. Las compañías colombianas que dependen del comercio con Estados Unidos se ven obligadas a realizar ajustes drásticos en sus operaciones. Los aranceles generan una necesidad urgente de buscar nuevos mercados, lo que implica rediseñar rutas logísticas, buscar nuevos socios comerciales, contratar nuevos proveedores y adaptar los canales de distribución. Esto representa un aumento considerable en los costos logísticos, donde representan cerca del 17,9 % del total de la operación empresarial según la Encuesta Nacional de Logística. La volatilidad del tipo de cambio, especialmente la apreciación del dólar frente al peso colombiano, encarece aún más el transporte internacional y los pagos a proveedores externos. No solo se encarecen las importaciones y exportaciones, sino que se compromete la calidad del servicio y la satisfacción del cliente. La imposición de aranceles se convierte entonces en un multiplicador de costos ocultos para los negocios colombianos. La adopción de tecnologías logísticas, como sistemas de gestión de transporte y herramientas de trazabilidad, se vuelve esencial para contrarrestar el impacto económico de los aranceles.

title: Sheinbaum y Trump hablan por teléfono para tratar ‘temas comerciales’
content: Sheinbaum y Trump retoman diálogo comercial mientras crecen tensiones por remesas y veto a exportaciones de ganado.
resumen: La presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, reveló que sostuvo una nueva llamada telefónica con su homólogo estadounidense, Donald Trump, para continuar con las negociaciones en temas comerciales. Sheinbaum anunció que el secretario de Economía, Marcelo Ebrard, viajará a Washington en los próximos días para sostener una reunión. La mandataria explicó que las conversaciones con Trump continúan en buenos términos y que mantienen una comunicación fluida. “La séptima llamada no será la última”, indicó, al precisar que seguirán tratando temas relacionados con el comercio y los aranceles. Recordó que México goza de una posición privilegiada en el sector automotriz, aunque insistió en que su gobierno busca mejorar aún más las condiciones. La conversación entre los mandatarios ocurre en medio de nuevas presiones económicas. Esta semana, la Cámara de Representantes aprobó una tasa del 3,5% a las remesas enviadas por migrantes, una medida que el gobierno mexicano rechaza por considerarla una violación al tratado bilateral de 1994 contra la doble tributación. Washington suspendió la importación de ganado mexicano tras detectar casos del gusano barrenador en el sur del país.

title: Claudia Sheinbaum y Donald Trump reanusan diálogos en medio de negociaciones comerciales
content: La presidenta mexicana Claudia Sheinbaum comunicó que mantuvo contactos telefónicos con Donald Trump. Las negociaciones comerciales avanzan entre ambos países, reportan fuentes oficiales.
resumen:
La presidenta mexicana, Claudia Sheinbaum, informó sobre una nueva conversación telefónica con el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, en el marco de las negociaciones comerciales entre ambos países.
No se alcanzó ningún acuerdo concreto en esta ocasión, pero se destacó la importancia de continuar con una relación fluida y una buena comunicación.
El secretario de Economía, Marcelo Ebrard, viajará a Washington para seguir con las pláticas.
Ebrard también abordó con Trump el "arancel del 25% sobre acero y aluminio".
Sheinbaum y Trump ya habían mantenido otra conversación telefónica después de que el mandatario estadounidense había decidido "relajar los aranceles en los sectores automotriz y de autopartes".
La reciente decisión de eliminar estos aranceles fue celebrada en México, donde la industria automotriz es fundamental, ya que más del 80% de su producción se exporta hacia el mercado estadounidense.
Sheinbaum celebró el avance en la Cámara de Representantes, que aprobó reducir el gravamen sobre remesas del 5% al 3,5%.
El gobierno mexicano y los congresistas han iniciado un intercambio de ideas con las autoridades estadounidenses, buscando asegurar que las remesas, que en el año pasado alcanzaron los 64.745 millones de dólares, no se vean afectadas.
Estas representaron cerca del 3% del Producto Interno Bruto (PIB) mexicano.

title: Guyana’s army chief says Venezuelans participating in Essequibo vote risk arrest
content: Guyana is warning that anyone living in the South American country who participates in upcoming elections organized by neighboring Venezuela over a disputed region will be charged with crimes ...
resumen: Guyana’s defense chief, Brig. Gen. Omar Khan, warned that any residents who participate in upcoming elections organized by Venezuela over the disputed Essequibo region will be charged with treason and other felony crimes. The May 25 election organized by Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro is the latest step in a push to annex the Essequibo region, which Venezuela has long claimed as its own. Venezuelans living in Guyana who become involved in Sunday’s elections could also face arrest and deportation. Nearly 100,000 people of direct or indirect Venezuelan ancestry currently live in Guyana, according to Foreign Secretary Robert Persaud. The Essequibo region represents two-thirds of Guyana and is rich in gold, diamonds, timber and other natural resources. It also is located close to massive offshore oil deposits, with current production averaging some 650,000 barrels daily. On Sunday, Venezuelans will head to the polls to elect governors and lawmakers, as well as officials who would supposedly administer the Essequibo region. In 2023, Maduro threatened to annex the region by force after holding a referendum asking voters if Essequibo should be turned into a Venezuelan state. The dispute over the region began more than a century ago, when an international tribunal in 1899 drew the border between the South American neighbors. In 2018, Guyana went to the International Court of Justice and asked judges to uphold the 1899 ruling. Meanwhile, Venezuela has dismissed the border drawn more than a century ago, noting Guyana was still a British colony. The case is still pending in court while tensions between the two countries keep rising despite an emergency summit held in late 2023 to diffuse the situation. Last week, Guyana’s government reported three separate attacks from the Venezuelan side on Guyanese soldiers patrolling a border river. Earlier this year, six Guyanese soldiers were injured in a separate attack. U.S. Ambassador Nicole Theriot has dismissed Maduro’s threats.
